dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three lane highway relegated to one lane.  The serpenti line of cars bottlenecks as it slithers by.  An arch of ORANGE AND RED FLARES outlines the area of shattered glas and twisted metal. We are at the site of a gruesome car accident.  An ambula and four police cars are on the scene.  Two cars are invo in the crash.  The first, a SILVER CADILLAC with its fron caved in a perfect semi-circle; there is no-one inside th car. The second car is a different story entirely.  A DARK GRE HONDA PRELUDE crushed against the concrete median that separates the South-bound lanes from the North-bound lane All the windows have imploded.  The original seventeen fo length of the car, compressed to ten.  The hood has folde back into the front seat.  This car is not empty!  Throug the sliver that used to be a window, WE SEE a female hand purple, swollen and bloody. Some drivers have stopped their cars on the shoulder and walked over to the flares.  A set of cops wave them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back in your cars and continue with the traffic.  There is nothing you can do. (beat) Get back in your cars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFFICER PIERCE speaks to a female OFFICER DANA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been dead about ten minutes. The jaws are on the way... Ran a license check.  Her name is Ellen Parker.  Forty-two years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him? Pierce gestures to a HISPANIC TEENAGER who is cuffed behi his back and being led to a police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit... How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen.  It's his grandfather's car.  On his way back from drinking with the 'boys'. Pierce lets it sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do we contact for her? Dana checks the papers in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her husband.  Maurice Parker.  They live in Wynnewood.  Married seventeen years. Pierce looks back at what remains of the HONDA PRELUDE. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't any good left in the world, Dana.  Not one damn thing. CLOSE UP of the hypnotic RED AND BLUE LIGHTS that consume highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just AFTER DAWN.  A gentle mist hangs in the air.  The ca suburban streets wait to be flooded with a sea of middle class homeowners on their way to work... A woman's REEBOK CROSS-TRAINERS move along the sidewalk.. long, brisk steps, steps people have when walking with a purpose... The Cross-Trainers enter the doors of a bakery store seco after a man turns a window-sign from "CLOSED" to "OPEN".. This happens with precision timing, not losing a step... well practiced routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGELO, a large man, black slicked hair -- has laid out t identical loaves of RAISIN BREAD on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good batch today. We finally see the person standing in the REEBOK CROSS TRAINERS... MRS. ELLEN PARKER, a woman in her forties wit heart-warming smile and wise glint in her eyes.  The kind woman that somehow becomes more beautiful with age. She carefully squeezes each loaf.  Her hand hovers over t middle loaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes later.  The basket of the "chosen" raisin bread is placed on the center of a table.  Ellen covers i with a cloth napkin. The eggs sizzle in a pan.  We find Ellen cooking breakfas A stunning African Grey Parrot sits proudly on Ellen's shoulder.  CLAUDE is a breathtaking creature with grey feathers and a cherry red tail. The DOOR BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: where a delivery man hands over a bouquet of VIOLET ORCHI Claude, still perched on Ellen like a clothing accessory, spreads his impressive wings defensively.  The delivery m scans the far wall to find a collection of bird photograp A dazzling collection of all kinds of birds, elaborately framed and hung. Ellen signs the release and closes the door.  She takes a deep smell of the violet orchids and looks down the hall the open bedroom door with a glowing smile.  We CATCH A GLIMPSE of a man dressing.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Where Ellen and her husband are eating breakfast.  Claude now in a cage in the hallway. MR. MAURICE PARKER eats a buttered piece of raisin bread. is a man in his late forties, neatly combed hair, his New York Times folded into a manageable rectangle.  This is a who has been seated a great deal of his life... the type man who breaks into a sweat when taking out the garbage. He feels a stare and looks up to find his wife with that glowing smile.  He smiles back. Ellen gestures with her eyes to the violet orchids now displayed proudly on the window ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flowers... they're beautiful. Maurice studies them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are... who sent them? Beat.  This takes Ellen by surprise.  Maurice catches the expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought I sent them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) There was no card. Maurice reaches over and searches the bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I forgotten something?  Is this a special day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat) It's just a regular day. Maurice pulls out a small bent card from between the stem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from Dan and Kate Wilkins... for dinner last week... Maurice hands Ellen the card, she looks at it unintereste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a special day isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure it's not Christmas, because you'd be worried about how much money we don't have to spend on each other... I know it's not New Years, because you'd be going on and on about wearing a tuxedo and how much you don't like to dance... and I'm sure it's not our anniversary, because I didn't find an envelope with a hundred dollars cash on my bureau with a note that says, 'Pick out something pretty'... Yes -- Maurice -- I'm virtually certain it's not a special day today. Ellen begins to eat.  Maurice stares at her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mad at me... You were beaming a minute ago, but since I didn't send the flowers... now you're mad at me. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I send flowers?  What's the occasion. Ellen instantly becomes emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Occasion?  Because you love me... That's the occasion. Ellen returns to eating.  Maurice stares at her quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHAFT OF LIGHT penetrates the darkness of a room... gro LARGER as the door swings open. Ellen steps in first followed by Maurice.  Ellen goes straight for the blinds.  BURST OF LIGHT stab the room. The spines of the BOOKS catch the light... rows and rows books cradled by a maze of mahogany book shelves.  This i old-fashioned store with antique chairs at select places. coffee table sits near the window with a set of deep cushioned sofa-chairs.  This store is a home... Maurice moves behind the counter and TURNS ON THE RADIO. CHOPIN FLOWS from the old speakers atop the corner shelve delicately. Ellen opens the door to the store and locks it in that position with a slanted piece of wood... The store is now open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a dozen people wander the isles.  Maurice's eyes dri to a pair of eleven year olds who have sauntered into the store.  One boy disappears behind "Philosophy" and reappe momentarily with his sweat-shirt zipped up to his neck -- rectangle is outlined under his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see that! Maurice comes around the corner -- the boys HAUL ASS out the store.  They're long gone before Maurice reaches the door.  He yells after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting a Doberman!  Two! Ellen who is sitting in the back room doing the accounts, comes out when she hears the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been saying that for two years; I think they know you're bluffing. Maurice inspects the "Philosophy" section. Maurice looks up as a young man, early twenties, hurries KRIS REDDY walks past Maurice, his black locks of hair peeking out from under his Philadelphia Eagles cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Maurice) Lizy Bennett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Kris. Kris waves as he removes his jacket.  He is wearing a PAR BOOKS T-shirt underneath.  He pins an "Assistant Manager" on. Maurice thinks to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizy, Eliza... Elizabeth Bennett... (the answer comes to him) Pride and Prejudice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to be a full character's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They called her 'Lizy' in the book... (beat) Sorry I was late.  My jeep died on the way over from the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They printed your article on, 'Dry Verses Can Dog Food'... Very enlightening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer, here I come. Kris notices as Maurice goes back to searching the isles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never have children.  If they're not a burden to you, they're a burden to someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the end of his words) Kris, go to the pharmacy.  Ask Mr. Donnavan to get you a large bottle of Geritol... Tell him, Maurice has officially become a grumpy old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd they take this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nietzsche!... As if they're going to read Nietzsche. Maurice moves back behind the counter clearly irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pick on you because they can get a rise out of you... children can sense those things. Kris quickly opens his black shoulder bag and pulls out a mini-tape recorder.  He talks into it -- dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday -- August 24... Juvenile delinquency -- Are the victims to blame? CLICK.  The tape recorder returns to the bag.  Ellen star at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Story ideas.  I'll forget them otherwise. Ellen nods with realization.  Ellen and Kris turn their attention to Maurice who is mumbling to himself angrily. looks out the window to the street to see a familiar grou school boys waving at him tauntingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIMLY LIT.  Red and gold paper mache lanterns are sprinkl around the room.  WE FIND Ellen and Maurice polishing off dish of General Tso's Chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand square feet... We can add a used book section. Ellen is not listening.  She is staring at a young couple tables over, who can't take their eyes off each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next door is a jewelry store with a full-time security guard... He stands outside all day.  Let's see them try and take Nietzsche then... Maurice finally notices Ellen is not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping out of it) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I told you.  If it makes you happy, we should just do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tremendous amount of work -- moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can do it together. Maurice needed the support.  His face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: An empty table.  The dishes have been cleared.  Maurice a Ellen are opening their fortune cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your's say? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Love is shown through actions not just words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?  That's not a fortune... You will be rich... That's a fortune.  What you have is a statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it is -- is the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't follow. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice, what would you do for me? What would you do for our love? I'm not talking about saying, I'm talking about doing. Maurice notices the STRAIN IN HER VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this going to be similar to the flower incident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very emotional) Sometimes people need to see things done for them -- because sooner or later they don't believe the words anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his voice) You don't think I love you? Customers react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lowering the volume) I want to be shown... (beat) Maurice would you do anything for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me?  Would I swim across an ocean for you?... Would I walk across the United States for you?  Yes... Yes I would.  You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) No I don't.  I don't even know if you'd walk across the street for me. Maurice is getting redder by the second.  The entire restaurant hangs on his response...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what have you done for me that's so earth-shattering? The waiter closest to the table cringes with Maurice's wo Ellen drains of color.  She stares at him in complete and utter disbelief.  She drills him with this iron glare for eternity then grabs her purse and heads to the exit.  Mau stares at the table for a moment to gather what's left of dignity and follows her out. The waiter moves to the table and clears the aftermath. sees Ellen's fortune crumpled next to her tea cup.  He unravels it.  The fortune reads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is LIT BY ONE BEDSIDE LAMP.  Maurice is sitting bed wearing a robe.  Reading glasses at the end of his no as he rubs a yellow cloth over a SILVER MEDALLION.  The medallion has a raised picture of a lamp, the kind Aladdi uses, seated on an open book and the words BOOK SOCIETY - 1992.  Maurice meticulously rubs away the smudge marks. Ellen is at the edge of the bed -- as far from Maurice as possible.  Her back is to him as she sleeps under the cov She speaks without turning around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you polish that thing all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you polish it? Maurice studies the impressive silver medallion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Book Society Award is a very prestigious thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you polishing it -- in bed -- in your pajamas -- at 11:15 at night?  Are you going to show it to someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  No reason.  No occasion. It just makes you feel good to do something for it, to express your pride and affection for it some how... (beat) How come you'd do that for a piece of metal and not for me? Maurice has no answer.  He just stares at his hands. ELLEN'S face can be seen under the covers facing away fro Maurice.  Her eyes are red.  The tears roll off her nose land on the pillow unseen and unheard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen table is mockingly empty.  No bread.  Not eve crumb.  Maurice, dressed for work, eyes the table with gr resolve.  He rubs his hands together ceremoniously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do this. Maurice moves to the fridge and gets out two eggs, onions green peppers and mushrooms. CLAUDE is chirping INCESSANTLY FROM THE HALL. The pile teeters precariously in Maurice's arms as he mov to the counter.  Next the pans come out -- He tries to pu the bottom pan from the cabinet --

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen is seated in bed, arms crossed -- equal resolve in face.  A LARGE METALLIC CRASH OF POTS ECHOES FROM DOWNSTA Ellen grabs her robe.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ellen gently takes Claude out of his cage.  She kisses hi The bird, once frantic, instantly at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) You missed mommie... worried when I didn't come down... my baby... so sweet. Ellen feeds the bird as she peeks around the corner, care not to be seen.  Maurice is desperately trying to cook an of control omelette.  It spills over the sides and SIZZLE the range top.  He tries to scoop it up with the pan, til it further -- further -- the entire omelette slides onto range.  Maurice frantically tries to wrangle it back in. vs. Egg.  Man losing. Ellen has to keep herself from laughing.  Her expression changes to pity as she watches the chaos unfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen scrutinizes a new three loaves of raisin bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one. Angelo smiles and packages the chosen loaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A defeated Maurice is eating an apple.  He looks up with surprise as Ellen walks into the kitchen from the back do a bag under her arm.  She glances at him and then moves t the counter where she prepares the bread for serving.  El looks down into the trash to find the rebellious omelette sitting uneaten. The bread gets laid out in its usual basket, in its usual manner.  Maurice says nothing as Ellen pulls two eggs fro the fridge and cracks them on a sizzling pan with expert ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onions? Maurice smiles warmly at his wife's back before moving to and hugging her from behind.  He whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you put up with me? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love... has something to do with it. Maurice reaches over and turns off the stove.  He then tu Ellen around and kisses her long and hard.  Ellen pulls a gently and stares into his eyes.  Maurice looks very emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do love you... very, very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with all his heart) I will -- I promise. Ellen kisses Maurice and returns to the eggs.  Maurice continues to hug her from behind.  The MORNING SUN pours the kitchen covering Ellen and Maurice in a golden bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large black man wearing a dress shirt, sleeves rolled u the elbows TURNS ON a switch.  A SET OF TUBE LIGHTS FLICK TO LIFE. CARL STONE leads Maurice out to the main room which is presently a cob-web infested, barren space with a few discarded packing boxes left in the corners. Maurice runs his fingertips against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History and the arts will be here... His hand makes a grand swirl pointing to another area.  H says the next two words with great awe as if he was sayin something holy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Classics... Carl watches curiously as Maurice walks around in a tranc He moves to the bay window that over looks the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have a hand-painted sign... (another grand swirl) ... Parker Books. Maurice's already bright eyes, brighten even more as he s the security guard strolling up and down the front of the jewelry store.  The guard catches his stare and waves. Maurice is aglow... He turns to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my dream... it's finally here. Carl has to smile -- rarely does he see someone so happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in Carl's cramped upstairs office... just enough r to walk amongst the file cabinets. Maurice holds his pen over the documents before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish my wife were here.  She should see this... (stalling) She had a doctors appointment in Blue Bell.  That's a one and a half hour drive.  Ellen's been going to that doctor since she moved to Pennsylvania...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding) We could do this tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen gave me strict orders to sign it... We invited some friends over -- you see, for a celebration. Carl smiles patiently, he's seen this before. Maurice gathers his strength as he puts pen to paper... H scribbles his signature quickly and let's the pen drop to table top as if all the energy drained from his body.  He looks up to Carl with powerful eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every journey begins with one step right? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy your party Mr. Parker... Your new store will be waiting for you Monday morning. Carl and Maurice shake hands like best friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wine chiller sits proudly on the coffee table.  The SOU OF LIGHT CONVERSATION float through the room.  About ten friends and family have gathered. Maurice sits on the sofa nearest the window.  He's listen to the drone of TED PRICE. Ellen is not present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... So she says the "L" word, after two dates, the "L" word!  She says 'Don't you believe in true love? Love that can conquer all?'  I say, 'Whoa, hold on.  Just so we're clear on things, I think love these days is shit.  It don't mean a thing and it don't stand for nothing.  Shit.'... You know what she says, 'Fine, but how do you feel about kids?' Everyone near the SOFA LAUGHS.  A CAR LIGHT DANCES ON THE CURTAINS... Maurice quickly pulls the curtain aside and watches as the car pulls past the house and around the corner.  Maurice turns back from the window hiding his concern and without missing a beat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to see you don't have any scars from your divorce. This brings on another ROUND OF LAUGHTER. THE TELEPHONE RINGS. Maurice rises from his seat -- but is waved off by ADELLE MATLIN who picks up the phone right away.  Adelle is Maurice's niece, early thirties, very attractive and alwa smiling -- except at this moment. Ted begins another one of his stories -- the words are incoherent as Maurice watches Adelle carefully... Adelle turns her back to the room as she talks and then DISAPPEA into the kitchen stretching the phone cord around the doorway... Something is definitely wrong. Maurice steadies his gaze at the door of the kitchen... eternal seconds pass before Adelle appears again.  She lo different -- ghostly.  She glances up for a fraction of a second locking eyes with her uncle -- she immediately loo away. Maurice watches Adelle move to her husband GERALD and whispers in his ear.  Gerald changes instantly -- taking the same ghostly transformation -- his eyes dart to Mauri Ted's story is cut off as Maurice speaks LOUDLY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? The room goes SILENT as all eyes fall on Adelle and Geral

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking) Maurice, can we go into the dining room? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened to my wife? This hits everyone in the room like a bomb.  A dread hang over every passing second... Gerald crumbles under the moment... Adelle begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a car accident... Drunk driver. Some of the crowd reacts.  A women covers her mouth.  The moment is unbearable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Please God -- don't do this. Gerald cracks -- the tears start to flow from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice, it was serious... I don't know how to -- Gerald buries his face into the heels of his palms as if trying to contain an explosion in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, please help me... She didn't... Ellen didn't make it... Ellen's dead Maurice. Maurice closes his eyes shut tightly... like a child scar of the dark. Adelle blacks out, knocking over the wine chiller on the to the ground.  In less than a minute the room has transformed from a celebration to a mourning.  Everyone i frozen staring at Maurice for their cue... A child in her mother's arms begins to cry as if aware of the circumstan EXTREME CLOSE UP.  Maurice opens his eyes slowly.  The ro stays still as Maurice stares at Ellen's HAT sitting on t piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "FTD" Florist truck pulls up.  A delivery man, moves wi an extravagant bouquet of flowers to the front door.  He RINGS THE DOOR BELL.  No answer.  KNOCKS.  No answer. The delivery man looks to the ground and searches, before placing the bouquet on the porch. WE NOW SEE that the porch is completely covered with flow bouquets and wreaths.  The delivery man tip-toes his way through the maze of condolences and moves to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice waits, as the SOUND OF THE FLOWER TRUCK FADES AWA then looks into Claude's cage.  Claude sits on the highes perch and continues to call to his mother.  Maurice stare the pile of untouched food on the floor of the cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat the food Claude...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Maurice seated at the kitchen table. He looks at the bouquet of flowers still seated on the wi sill.  The violet orchids are all dead and shriveled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house feels abandoned -- lifeless.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE IS SILENT EXCEPT FOR THE FRANTIC CHIRPING OF CL
dialogues.text: FROM THE HALL.  His hopeless cries punctuating the air ev few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Maurice sits in a chair facing Ellen's wardrobe closet. LIGHTS IN THE ROOM ARE OFF.  The room is lit only by the LIGHT FROM THE HALLWAY STREAMING IN AT AN ANGLE. Maurice gets up and with a great deal of uncertainty, ope the closet.  Maurice stares at the collection of hanging dresses. He reaches out and pulls the cloth of a floral dress towa him... He closes his eyes and smells the cloth... his fac tightens in pain... both hands cling to the dress tightly he tries desperately, can't fight it -- Maurice Parker be to cry. His hands grab frantically at the rest of the dresses -- pressing them to his face and chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God... I'm sorry Ellen... I'm so sorry... He hugs the dresses as if they were her.  His weeping tur to a torturous wail of grief... all the love, all the ang spilling out in this one moment. He falls to the ground yanking all the dresses down with -- they collapse atop him... He buries his face in his wi clothes... The MUFFLED SOUND OF HIS CRIES ECHOES through the lonely house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood park.  The trees in full bloom.  Maurice walks down a path leading to the open fields.  Only mothe with strollers and the elderly are out this early.

dialogues.speaker: PARK BENCH
dialogues.text: Maurice is seated on a park bench.  Across from him is an ELDERLY COUPLE -- in their seventies.  The OLD WOMAN is f with tiny eyes that disappear when she smiles.  The husba is a skinny man with a baseball hat that makes him look l a little boy. Maurice watches them silently as they sit and hold hands. Their warm laughs and whispered conversations stinging hi He watches as the old man gets up.  The old woman tries t make him stay, but he playfully pulls away.  She shakes h head like a shy school girl as the old man walks back dow the path by himself. The old woman glances Maurice's way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. The old woman glances at the empty baby carriage standing next to the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's not mine. Maurice gestures to the woman and baby who are sitting on blanket in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should.  Children are a blessing from God.  I have four. The old woman studies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your husband? She nods, "Yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look so happy -- how long have you been married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-seven years. This hits Maurice hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you married? This hits Maurice even harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is painful) Yes... Seventeen years. The old woman looks down the path for her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting my sweater from the car.  I said there was a breeze. (shaking her head) I told him not to go. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask you a question that might sound strange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know he loves you? The old woman looks at him oddly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean besides... time -- how did you know ten years ago -- twenty years ago? She thinks hard... tough question.  No answer for a momen then -- The old woman sees something out of the corner of her eye her husband is walking up the path with her white lace sweater over his arm... She smiles as the answer comes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he shows me... he's not much for words, but he shows me. Maurice sits back -- her answer lingers in the air like a haunting voice. Maurice watches as the old man comes back and drapes his with the sweater.  The old woman waves as they continue d the path... hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An obese woman with a hacking cough sits to the left of Maurice... To the right, a man with a patch over his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker... Maurice Parker. The nurse sticks her head outside the glass divider till Maurice stands up.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINATION ROOM
dialogues.text: DR. ROYCE checks a chart.  Maurice watches him from his p on the examination chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the deal Maurice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean why the sudden voluntary visit  -- usually it takes gun- point to get you in here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Routine, I assure you.  I just wanted to gage my health.  Am I healthy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to ask you a question that may sound peculiar. Dr. Royce folds his arms and waits... What's this all abo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far could an individual walk if they had no athletic training -- you understand, just an ordinary person? Dr. Royce stares at him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're getting at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're feeling old and you want to start exercising.  A lot of men your age feel the need to recapture their youth.  Don't feel embarrassed about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should start slow and easy -- fifteen minutes a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  How far in one attempt -- what's the farthest someone like myself could walk? The doctor is confused again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for curiosity sake that's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- maybe twenty miles... Of course I'm not recommending that... if someone like you had to I mean... that's how far they'd probably get before encountering serious physical walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty miles?  I see. Maurice thinks about it carefully as the doctor returns t the chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hip young woman with her forehead wrapped in a headband chews away on a stick of gum.  JOSELLE leans over the cou with Maurice and studies a map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each inch represents 150 miles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making the grand total?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn baby, relax.  I'm getting to it. (taking on a rehearsed tone) From Philadelphia following the route highlighted to Pacifica California -- you're traveling an estimated three thousand two hundred miles... Maurice is a bit pale.  He follows the yellow highlighted highways winding it's way across the U.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three thousand miles?... How many times does twenty go into three thousand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps there's another route?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the route approved by triple A.  Even if you followed back roads the entire way, you'd still be looking at roughly the same distance... Joselle studies his concerned expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry baby, it shouldn't take you more than five days if you just stop to sleep and eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By car right? Joselle scrunches her face in exaggerated shock and takes step back to look Maurice up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How else you gonna get there on the ground? Maurice gives her a sad expression.  If she only knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The future Parker Books.  The room sits as empty and barr as before. Maurice sits on the floor against the far wall.  He stare his new store.  His gaze turns to the window where the gu strolls by.  The guard doesn't notice him. Maurice looks terrible, his eyes red and framed by bags.. his skin a yellowish white. He moves to his feet and TURNS OFF THE LIGHTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kris unloads the last of a shipment of books.  He moves t Maurice who sits by the window to the street.  Maurice po to a chair across from him and Kris takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want to be a journalist Kris?  What sparked your interest? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to reach people.  Nobody listens to me.  This is my way to reach them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To reach people, you have to feel something first... You write about the wrong things.  How can you feel for dog food?  The people at the Gazette don't respect it, and neither do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a ghost town.  Nothing ever happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write from your heart.  That's why the classics are great. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me this Mr. Parker? Maurice looks out the window and picks up an envelope fro the coffee table between them.  He hands it to Kris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bus is arriving. Kris opens the envelope and finds money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one month's pay. Kris gets up.  A shock of adrenaline hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you firing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No... I won't be here for a while.  The store will be closed in the interim. Kris grabs his coat, shifting his attention between the window and Maurice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going on a trip Mr. Parker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California. Kris moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cool.  What day are you arriving? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure -- sometime in January I think. Kris stops cold.  The door to the street half-open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Kris is seriously confused now.  Maurice decides to end t confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm walking there Kris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California. Kris' jaw hits the floor as the bus pulls to a stop acros the street.  Kris pulls up his sleeve and glances at his forearm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hairs on my arm are standing up... Something strange is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always knew you had good instincts... (beat) Goodbye Kris.  I'll see you when I get back. Kris hesitates before darting out of the store, across th street and into the bus.  Kris takes a seat in the back a digs into his bag and pulls out the tape recorder.  CLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday, September 25... 'The Death Of A Spouse - Can It Drive You Insane?'

dialogues.speaker: A BRILLIANT RED HUE BLANKETS THE HORIZON.
dialogues.text: The suburbs come to life... Men and women leaving for work... School buses picking up their cargo of passengers... Store owners opening their businesses...

dialogues.speaker: PARKER BOOKS
dialogues.text: A group of eleven year old boys including the two kleptomaniacs we saw earlier, are standing before a close door staring at a sign.  They look at each other before heading down the block. The sign reads:  CLOSED - OWNER OUT OF TOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is eerily silent. Three things lay on the dining table.  A shoulder bag fil with clothes.  A carrying bag with personals.  And a set maps. Maurice checks the locks on all windows... He places all food in the refrigerator into a trash bag... He pulls out drawer and loosens a side panel, a wad of money flops out Maurice pockets the bills... Maurice walks through the hall with a portable cage.  He stops before Claude's hanging cage... no movement, no chirping.  Maurice stares emotionally for a moment before reaching in and carefully removing CLAUDE'S LIFELESS BODY from the bottom of the cage.  Maurice looks down at the l pet in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice buries the bird in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Maurice sits at the table... the essentials laying before him.  He clings to a wallet size photo of Ellen. Maurice stands and gathers his things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice stands at the edge of the water.  Recreations of historical ships are docked in the harbor.  The old fashi sails and masts sway in the gentle breeze. The SOUNDS OF A STREET VENDOR catch Maurice's ears.  He t to see a funnel cake booth in a row of food stalls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The harbor is jammed with people.  A street fair is in fu swing.  The SOUNDS OF A LIVE BAND MIX WITH THE CRIES OF T STREET VENDORS... MAURICE -- EARLY TWENTIES... Skinny, dark rich hair.  He yells out from behind a booth of paperback books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three dollars a piece... Two for four dollars!  All the classics! A young woman emerges from the crowd of browsers.  Mauric begins to speak but is caught off guard by YOUNG ELLEN'S beautiful features.  Maurice manages a few words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father owns the food stall over there. Maurice looks over to find an enormous man serving food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look thirsty. Ellen places the soda she had at her side on the table. Maurice is completely flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Ellen. Ellen places her hand out.  Maurice grabs it instinctivel and shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice. Ellen looks at the full table of books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not doing too good huh? Maurice nods "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll pick up.  I've been coming to these things my whole life... people don't want to carry things as they walk around... you'll sell as the fair starts to end... Ellen waits for Maurice to say something but nothing come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't talk much do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read a lot. Ellen's father BELLOWS FOR HER OVER THE CROWD.  Maurice j at the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better go... (Ellen starts for her booth) ... Come over if you get hungry. Ellen disappears into a sea of people.  Maurice stands in for a second before snapping out.  He shakes his head to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read a lot?

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The people are filing out of the street.  Maurice is a wh wind of activity as people wave dollar bills at him calli out classical titles. Maurice glances over to Ellen's booth.  She is watching h with a big smile.  Maurice gestures to the line with a shocked expression.  Ellen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FOOD STALL
dialogues.text: The booths are packing up.  Ellen helps pack away the remaining food.  A book is placed in front of her on the counter.  The book is "Romeo and Juliet."  Ellen looks up see a very shy Maurice standing before her.  Ellen gives a smile that melts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell me something? Beat.  Maurice eyes Ellen's dad who throws him deadly glances.  Maurice is very intimidated.  He whispers to he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Walk with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to take walks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But I want to take a walk with you. Ellen looks at him carefully... looks right through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just said something very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water reflects the lights from the harbor.  Maurice a Ellen are standing very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking? Ellen looks out onto the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of those thoughts you keep to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell me. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking that if we actually became a couple -- this was a beautiful place to begin things. Maurice is bright red.  Ellen giggles at his shyness. Maurice gathers his strength and looks her straight in th eyes. Maurice leans forward and kisses her softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice, tears in his eyes, stands in the spot they stood many years before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I love you Ellen. On this empty dock... on this hot day in September... wit witnesses and no fan-fare, Maurice Parker takes the first steps of his journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A topless CHERRY RED WRANGLER JEEP pulls out of a mechani garage and moves down route 32.  Kris Reddy is at the whe A "Daily Gazette" sign flaps from his roll-bar. Kris changes the station on the radio as his eye catches man walking on the opposite side of the street... Kris tu back to the road -- mind racing... BRAKES SCREECH as the slows and then RUMBLES over the island separating the lanes... making a U turn across a four lane highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice wiping his brow with a handkerchief.  The Wrangle jeep rolls up next to him as he walks.  Maurice doesn't s walking as Kris leans over the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phileas Fogg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking ahead) ... Round The World In Eighty Days. ... Hello Kris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're amazing... What are you doing Mr. Parker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. Beat.  Cars HONK as they pull by the slow duo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're walking to California?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacifica, California -- it's a coastal city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a coastal city.  That's good. Kris looks around to see if anyone else sees the lunacy i this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen told me that she didn't know if I loved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knew you loved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't certain... I never really showed her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really lost.  What does this have to do with walking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, 'I would do anything for her'... and she didn't believe me. I said, 'I'd walk across the country for her'... she didn't believe me. Maurice looks to Kris rolling along beside him.  He sees worried expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to show her how much I love her Kris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I should have shown her before... Everyday, I should have shown her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacifica, California... that's a long ways away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I've been informed. Kris tries to act calm, but it doesn't last long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit Mr. Parker.  You can't walk across the United States -- it's over three thousand miles. Maurice takes his time with the response.  Kris waves mor cars to pass them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen got up every morning and went to the corner store to get me my bread for breakfast... Everyday. Now that's about a quarter mile each way... 17 years... that comes to about three thousand miles... (he smiles to himself) And you know what Kris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Mr. Parker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never ate a slice. Maurice picks up speed -- surer with every step... Kris s the jeep to a stop and reaches into his bag.  The mini ta recorder goes on with a CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday, September 26... 'The Question We Never Ask - What Would We Do For Love?' Kris watches through the windshield as Mr. Parker disappe down Route 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wreaths, flowers and bouquet have now tripled in numb They spill onto the lawn and walkway.  A neighborhood dog rummages through the more colorful bouquets.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: The abandoned house.  A TELEPHONE RINGS CONTINUOUSLY.  It stops after a string of rings.  It BEGINS AGAIN AFTER A F SECONDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark bookcases echo the RINGS OF THE TELEPHONE.  The answering machine finally picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello you've reached Parker Books -- our store hours are eight to six...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A center-city Town house.  Wall to wall books, "Cognitive Psychology", "Physiology of Behavior", "Abnormal Psycholo "Clinical Psychology", the titles cover every shelf and e tabletop. Adelle Matlin hangs up the phone, and moves to the living room where her husband is reading a paper in his recliner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's wrong.  I'm worried. Gerald looks on with an assuring smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably just went somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a walk.  I don't know. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Maurice?  Are you kidding? He hates walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nighttime.  The empty street ECHOES with the TIRED SHUFFL MAURICE'S FEET. Maurice stops in this tracks and picks up a CRUSHED COKE FROM THE SIDE OF THE ROAD.  He places it upright at the p where he stands.  Maurice immediately walks off the highw into a small MOTEL PARKING LOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motel clerk checks his wooden keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pool times are 11 am to 5 pm, there's cable in every room with two premium channels.  HBO and CINEMAX.  Pay Per View Channels can be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a bed and I need Tylenol... that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room comes with two twin Sealy Posturepedics... but the Tylenol will be extra. Maurice stares at him with exhausted eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THE INSIDE OF A FLORAL PRINTED ROOM
dialogues.text: Maurice's shoulder bags are on the bed... The WATER IS RUNNING IN THE BATHROOM. Maurice gently moves his hands under the bathtub head, checking the temperature.  He sits on the edge of the tub Maurice peels off his shoes with great pain.  They slide across the dull white tiles into the corner.  The once we kept English Loafers could be mistaken for trash now. Maurice rubs his barefeet with both hands -- grimacing fr the pain.  The tub is almost filled.  Maurice stops the t The steam from the water fills the room. Maurice raises his legs with great effort and submerges e leg into the steaming water.  His eyes close with great relief as his body melts into the tub.  Maurice lays his on the side of the tub... It only takes ten seconds befor Maurice's SNORING fills the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: THE OUTSIDE OF THE QUAKER MOTEL ON ROUTE 32
dialogues.text: The neon MOTEL SIGN THROBS RED. SUPERIMPOSED across this image are the words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice looks down the highway... eyes squinting to block the sun.  The road winds and dissolves into the horizon.. Maurice looks back the way he came -- a second of indecision... the moment passes. Maurice takes a deep breath before moving to the CRUSHED CAN.  He moves to the exact spot where he left the road t night before and begins walking again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator BELL dings, letting off a cargo of newspaper personnel.  FRANK AND SETH are two of them.  They make th way to the desks... a sea of desks pressed against each o -- each desk has a computer. Frank and Seth come to their corner and stop before a you man, Phillies cap turned backwards, sitting behind an IBM DX... fingers flying over the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's got a hot story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time did you get in? Kris Reddy keeps typing.  He spits out the answer after a seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five... Couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this one about Kris? 'Blinds or Curtains - The Eternal Question?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... 'Boxers Verses Tight Undies - The Battle Continues.' Frank and Seth crack up laughing.  Frank reaches for the printouts... Kris immediately covers them with his hand. stares up with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read about it on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice exits an athletic store in a small town.  On his a new pair of sneakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice as he walks down a winding highway.  His new snea shuffling slowly. A SHARP PAIN SHOOTS UP MAURICE'S LEG.  His knees buckle. shoulder bags tumble to the ground followed by Maurice himself.  From a distance it looks like he's been shot. Maurice grabs the back of his thigh and tries to straight his leg out... His face frozen in a painful expression. Maurice rubs his legs slowly -- working the cramp out.  H relaxes a bit as he finally straightens his leg.  Maurice sits there motionless -- eyes glazed... defeated. The SOUNDS OF A BIRD snap him out of his trance.  He look to see a PAINTED BUNTING, a bird about six inches in heig FLY DOWN from a tree and land on a rock next to him.  Mau stares at the beautiful bird curiously.  Its body splashe with brilliant blues, reds and greens.  It looks out of p in these mundane surroundings.  Maurice looks around the skies to see no other birds.  The Painted Bunting chirps few times before taking flight into the air.  It circles Maurice before disappearing behind the trees. Maurice smiles.  He pulls himself to his feet with great effort. Maurice opens all of his bags and begins emptying the essentials -- the maps, food, a canister of water. Maurice reloads one bag and pulls it over his shoulder wi great effort.  At his feet, are the rest of his belonging piled on the side of the road. Maurice painfully begins walking again. WE PULL BACK on Maurice's figure walking on the highway.. the pile of disregarded things laying by the side... The highway is endless... winding it's way for miles and mile into a fixed dot in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunrise on Pennsylvania.  Gerald picks the Philadelphia Gazette off the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerald flips open the paper as he waits before an empty plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells good, honey.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Adelle puts the finishing touches on a stack of pancakes. She sets up two plates and brings them into the

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerald's eyes remain glued to the paper.  Adelle comes to table, holding the golden pancakes over the table.  She notices the strange look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelle... Maurice is in the paper. She stares silently at the paper laid out on the table. headline beams at her:

dialogues.speaker: A PHILADELPHIA NATIVE'S LABOR OF LOVE
dialogues.text: Adelle is shocked.  She gazes at an old picture of her un printed underneath the headline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. She STORMS off into the kitchen with the golden pancakes. Gerald looks down at his empty plate longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERGEANT DALLY pretends to be concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like us to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put out a P.B.S.... Or whatever it's called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.P.B.... He isn't breaking any law.  He's a grown man... He can crawl on his hands and knees to China if that's what he wants to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, I'm a psychologist and I know the difference between normal whims people have and actions that clearly display psychological problems... My uncle lost his wife and it devastated him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're very sorry about that.  Some of our men were on the scene of the accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think my uncle is suffering from a condition called Mania which is linked with depression.  It is a time when an individual will act over-confident, and will act out impractical, grandiose plans. Sometimes these plans can be dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does this... Mania last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple days to a few months if untreated. Dally digests this information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll see if anyone has spotted him recently.  If I get any information, I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wait by the phone.  If he's really been walking this whole time, he's out of our jurisdiction... Adelle looks very emotional... on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry he'll be back.  He's in his forties.  He's had no physical training... He'll be back by the end of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A floating DOT moves along a flat stretch of road...

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: The sun drops behind rolling hills.  The DOT has become LARGER, sprouting arms and legs...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darkness has fallen.  The DOT has materializes into MAURI

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL
dialogues.text: A clerk hands over a set of keys in exchange for money.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Maurice walks back onto the highway and steps next to an boot that has been used as today's MARKER.  Maurice start walking from that point.

dialogues.speaker: DRUGSTORE
dialogues.text: Maurice grabs two handfuls of small green boxes.  He plac them on the table.  The cashier stares down at the eight boxes of Ben-Gay and rings it up.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Maurice standing at the entrance to a tunnel that pierces side of a mountain side.  Maurice makes "The sign of the cross" and walks into the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: EXIT OF TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Maurice appears on the other side with a smile of relief. He's awed at the beauty of the landscape.  Tiny clusters buildings far in the distance wrapped in a blanket of gre for miles on every side.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL
dialogues.text: Maurice asleep in the bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: It's raining hard like gun-fire from the sky.  Maurice si on the edge of a road rubbing his legs.  His hair matted his head.  The rain pelts the ground in forceful waves.

dialogues.speaker: SUPPLY STORE
dialogues.text: At a cash register, Maurice slaps ten more boxes of Ben-G down on the counter.  A teenage girl with braces looks at like he's Charles Manson.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL
dialogues.text: Maurice sleeps.  His barefeet are propped up on his bag. feet are swollen and red with fresh blisters.  A pack of is wrapped around his knee with an old shirt... The pictu of Ellen clutched in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Two joggers pass Maurice as he sees a flashing school sig It is a suburban town.  The fallen red and orange leaves cover every flat surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of cars pulls around a semi-circle driveway.  Maur watches as parents drop off their children.  A couple of year old boys walk by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice sneaks. Maurice realizes they're talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure man, High-Top Nike Cross Trainers with heel supports and air cushioned soles -- They're nasty. The boys keep walking.  Maurice looks down at his sneaker with new-found pride. After a while, Maurice's attention switches back to the c One car in question catches Maurice's eye.  A woman conso a small child who doesn't want to leave the car.  She wip his tiny tears with her hand and hugs him tenderly.  The little boy's head cradled in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Parker house many years ago.  The house semi-furnishe Ellen carefully hangs her first bird photographs on the w a striking aerial photo of a GOLDEN EAGLE.  Wings spread, soaring high over a mountain range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we both wanted the same things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't change your mind. Beat.  Ellen takes a seat on the only sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've just decided, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Young Maurice is visibly upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen, there are two kinds of people in the world --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please not, 'The two kinds of people' speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... People that were made to be parents, and people who were not made to be parents... My parents, were people who were not made to be parents but had kids anyway.  I don't want us to be that way Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face it Ellen, I'm not the type of person who reads bedtime stories. But you love me anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset) Don't be so sure. Ellen fiddles with her dress.  She bites her bottom lip a she tries not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaky voice) What if something happens to one of us?  We'll be all alone. Maurice loses his hard demeanor and moves next to her.  H lays his hand across her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing will happen to us.  It's a bleak picture, I know, but we're going to be together till were old and grey and you don't remember my name anymore. Maurice lifts her chin with his hand gently.  She blinks eyes and a tear rolls down her cheek.  He takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me think about it okay. Ellen brightens up immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying anytime soon.  I'm just saying that maybe we can consider it down the road sometime. Ellen gives her patented glowing smile.  She hugs him wit all her strength.  She whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you Maurice Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice walks away from the school, shuffling through the piles of leaves that block the walkways. A child and her father walk down the path towards him. Maurice looks away painfully.  THE CHILD'S SOFT LAUGHTER POUNDING IN HIS EARS as he quickens his pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKSON LIQUOR WHOLESALERS.  For the kind of people who b whiskey by the crate. Maurice has his map unfolded over the cash register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can show you the main roads, but that'll add ten miles to your trip. Do you mind ten miles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mind.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE OF LIQUOR STORE
dialogues.text: The parking lot of the store looks like a used truck lot. Every kind of supped-up truck one could possibly imagine on display here. Maurice passes a CANARY YELLOW FLATBED PICK-UP with a gro of men drinking a newly purchased case of beer.  Maurice about ten feet past them when he stops, hesitates and the heads back to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, who's truck is this? The man sitting on the hood of the truck, has dark hair a hasn't shaven in days.  This unfortunate gentleman is nam DENNY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you and your friends planning on driving soon? Denny gives Maurice a greasy curious look.  He squints hi glazed eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes we are.  Who the fuck are you? Maurice, doesn't look scared, in fact he looks angered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know me from Adam, but I want you to do something for me.  I want you to wait until you sobered up before you get behind the wheel. I know this is out of the ordinary, but one man to another, would you do me that favor? Silence.  Then everyone in the group BURSTS OUT IN DRUNKE LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a preacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seething with anger) No, I just don't want anybody dying because I didn't say something when I had the chance. Denny's face goes blank.  No emotion.  His steady gaze al terrifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive my truck shit-faced if I want to.  You better turn around and walk away preacher.  You don't know who you're talking to. Maurice looks around at the hostile faces and decides on retreat.  Denny watches Maurice with predatory eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice practically hobbles his way down a road lined by towering pines.  He stops to take a drink from his canist and keeps walking.  The SOUNDS OF A CAR GROW IN THE DISTA Maurice doesn't turn his back. The CANARY YELLOW TRUCK pulls over the ridge with a load of passengers.  It gains distance on Maurice. Maurice hears the ENGINE and waves HIS ARM IN THE AIR -- signaling for it to pass him.  Maurice walks ten more fee before turning around. Maurice's face instantly changes when he sees the demente grins through the windshield of the truck.  Maurice turns quickens his pace... The truck picks up pace... Maurice breaks into a run... The truck speeds up, passes Maurice stops in front of him. Panic fills Maurice as he watches the truck unload it's drunken passengers.  Eyes scan the forest on either side a way out.  Maurice decides to stand his ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) This is Indiana -- nothing's going to happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a ride, Preacher? The men walk up to Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you I'll walk. A tall lanky gentleman gestures to Maurice's shoulder bag with his beer can.  Some beer sprays Maurice's feet with gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look gentlemen, I'm late, I need to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking -- who the hell is this preacher guy?  Coming up to me and my friends?  Looking like he wanted to kick my ass for drinking? Denny gives Maurice that inhuman stare.  Maurice is clear frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I figured it.  You're angry. You lost somebody, because some asshole was drinking. Maurice is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you lost a son?  A sister?  A wife? Maurice looks up for a millisecond.  Denny doesn't miss i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping closer) A wife?... Did someone piss drunk run into your wife?  Crushed her like a bug.  Snapped her bones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough. Maurice is red with anger.  Denny loves it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh the preacher's getting angry again... (Denny goes ice cold) Tell me something.  Did she die instantly or did she feel every torn muscle and shattered bone? Were you there to help her?  Or were you safe at home when the windshield sliced into her face --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill you! Maurice swings.  Denny easily avoids it.  Maurice doesn't the first BLOW COMING, IT HITS HIM IN THE CHEST -- Mauric gasps for air as he buckles to the dirt.  Hands grab -- restrain.  A POWERFUL KICK IN THE RIBS -- ANOTHER... LAUGHTER... ANOTHER SET OF VICIOUS KICKS... The road and forest begin to spin... A PAINFUL SLASH ACROSS HIS FACE.. Maurice prepares for the next blow... it never comes.  RE AND BLUE lights swirl... Maurice looks up, barely focusin a man leans over a car door... The image becomes clearer POLICEMAN stands poised -- gun aimed directly at the men hovering over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distorted and slowed) Step away from him now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFFICER MERRIL GREY -- balances a phone on his shoulder a spreads a new coat of mayonnaise on his hoagie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need an I.D. check on a Maurice A. Parker... Grey reads Maurice's license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's number 22 184 877... (listening) He was assaulted by a group of men just outside Elkhart, Indiana...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Dally, the officer Adelle spoke to earlier, list on the other end of the phone his mouth agape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he?... That's good. Gesturing to a young officer at another desk to come over Dally, cups the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Adelle Matlin... tell her we found her uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sea of desks are empty.  One empty desk is lit -- Kri Reddy's desk.  THE CRACKLE OF A SHORTWAVE/C.B. UNIT FLOAT THROUGH THE LARGE UNOCCUPIED ROOM from an adjacent room.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES OF DALLY AND OFFICER GREY ARE DISTORTED BUT AUDIBL
dialogues.text: WE MOVE TO the back room to find Kris writing furiously i front of an elaborate C.B. setup. He jots down the words as fast as they're said: "Maurice Parker... Elkhart... Route 80... Precinct 18..." The transmission gets cut as the phone conversation ends. Kris quickly rolls the chair across the room and grabs a off the shelf. The map gets pinned under two coffee cups and a ceramic f as Kris traces the route from Philadelphia to Indiana... sits up straight in astonishment as his eyes hit the KEY the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus -- he's walked six hundred miles. Kris glances at the hairs on his arm and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Kris at his computer and in the 'zone.'  Fingers flying o the keys passionately.  On his desk is a cardboard box fi with letters all shapes and sizes on the verge of overflo the top of the box.  One the side of the box are the word "Labor of Love - Fan Mail."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN IN INDIANA -- the sun spills over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice and Officer Grey are seated on the front stairs o the precinct drinking coffee when ADELLE MATLIN DRIVES UP Adelle steps out of a RENTED TOYOTA CELICA.  Her tense -- frightened eyes betray her mental state for the past ten hours.  She walks to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Matlin... good morning. Maurice slowly gets up.  Adelle is in shock as she looks the stranger before her. Maurice stands in a 'COLTS' football T-shirt, faded jeans sneakers.  His left cheek is black and blue, and his arm side are bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Maurice, you're wearing sneakers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High-top Nike Cross-Trainers with heel support and air-cushioned soles.  They're nasty. Adelle wasn't sure what that meant.  She shakes it off an hugs Maurice.  She is visibly relieved to have him in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shift ended an hour ago. Adelle notices the ROSE in Grey's hand.  Grey catches her glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the occasion? Grey looks to Maurice -- they exchange a knowing smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No occasion. Adelle notices the WINK exchanged between Grey and Mauric

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can use the conference room, if you want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can talk on the way back -- I rented a car. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be kind of hard to talk, since you'll be in the car and I won't. Adelle gives Maurice an angry glare -- Maurice holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conference room is down the hall on your right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: File cabinets in the corners.  A small rectangle table ta up ninety percent of the space in the room. Maurice is seated -- his legs extended straight on anothe chair.  Adelle paces the front of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your store?  What about your new store?  What about all your dreams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have new dreams now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't accept that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe one day -- after you've been married twenty years you'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Maurice -- I spent all our frequent flyer miles on a one way ticket here... I have a rented car outside, just listen to me. (beat) Come back with me now, and if you still want to do something like this in a year -- maybe we'll plan a car trip across the country -- Gerald and I will come along --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to walk -- by myself -- all the way -- every inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what she asked for... It's what I'm going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was being symbolic.  What if she asked you to fly to the moon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be visiting me at Nasa. Adelle changes gears.  She takes a seat next to Maurice a studies his legs and tired face carefully before uttering words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) What if you don't make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you really want to do this... plan it out.  Rest up.  Train for it.  Build up your body.  Plan every stop along the way.  How much money?  Time?  Really do it properly.  This is all so -- by the seat of your pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you take the back roads here?  They're not safe.  You'd know that if you'd planned. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've all ready gone six hundred miles... I can't do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't redo these six hundred miles when you're rested and ready, how are you possible going to walk another two thousand-five hundred miles in your present condition? Maurice is stumped.  He looks unsure.  He instantly looks the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle, the way I was told, if that police car didn't happen down that road, you would be dead right now. That guy Denny, had jumped bail in another state, he's dangerous... They'll be other Dennys, if you don't plan. Maurice stares down at the table -- the life draining fro him with every word she says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen, deserves you to do this right.  Really make it -- if you're going to do it.  She deserves it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RENTED TOYOTA CELICA turns out of the police station the main road. Adelle holds a cushion in the air as she looks in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want this?  It's a long ride. Maurice is stretched out in the back -- his legs propped on a blanket.  Maurice shakes his head "no" silently. His sad eyes watching the passing scenery.  The speeding swallows up the miles effortlessly.  Maurice watches the Jackson Liquor Wholesalers whiz by... The painful hills h climbed, gone, in an instant... The school where he watch the children being dropped off, swishes by in a blink... those miles lost. Maurice shuts his eyes in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rented Toyota Celica is parked at the convenience sto Maurice is seated in the back staring out at the eighteen wheelers that come in and out of the parking lot.  He gla in to Adelle who is gathering food. Maurice's dull eyes are about to shut when something catc his attention.  He sits up and stares out the window with great intensity.  Maurice watches as a large truck pulls the parking lot, across it's side in blazing red -- "Jackson Liquor Wholesalers - Since 1945" Maurice scans the area... gas station ATTENDANTS... A BEA HOMELESS MAN laying next to a heating unit... KIDS eating fast food on old picnic tables... Maurice's gaze steadies on the TRUCK, as the driver fills tank with gas.

dialogues.speaker: A PHONE BOOTH INSIDE THE CONVENIENCE STORE
dialogues.text: Adelle is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll figure everything out when we get there... Oh, he's going to need a lot of help with this... He wasn't even going to come with me, I had to tell him that he could do the walk later if he plans well... I know, but by that time I'll have gotten him some treatment... I just want to get back home before he changes his mind.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: Adelle gets in the front seat of the car keeping the bag food on the passenger seat.  She starts the car as she ta into the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something to eat? She stares at Maurice covered in a blanket with his back her... an unresponsive blob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're feeling a lot of emotions right now.  It's okay to be mad.  It's okay to feel helpless.  It's part of the healing process.  I understand.  I do. Adelle puts the Celica into drive and pulls out onto the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening in Philadelphia.  The rented Toyota Celica pulls the driveway.  The front door of the house opens.  Gerald walks out to greet them. A tired Adelle slips out of the car and hugs Gerald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was exhausted -- slept the whole way. Adelle and Gerald move to the back door of the Celica.  T open it and stare at Maurice covered by the blanket.  Ade shakes the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Maurice we're home... Uncle Maurice. Adelle shakes Maurice, who stirs a little as he wakes.  H feet slide out from under the blanket -- Adelle stares curiously at the ARMY COMBAT BOOTS that dangle out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Maurice? Adelle pulls aside the covers... THE HOMELESS MAN, from t gas station, sits up.  ADELLE'S SHRILL SCREAM BLASTS THRO THE AIR.  Gerald and Adelle stumble back as the large, bearded man struggles out of the car and looks around the quiet neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is the City of Brotherly Love. The homeless man raises his hand.  He holds up MAURICE'S POLISHED BOOK SOCIETY MEDALLION and kisses it lovingly. Adelle and Gerald stare back speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
