dialogues.text: JACKSON WHOLESALER'S PARKING LOT.  The truck from the gas station, the only vehicle parked before the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice back on the road.  His limp only slightly visible this point in the day.  The bandages rubbing him with eve step. The highway takes him around a beautiful bend of trees. AIR IS FILLED WITH THE SOUNDS OF BIRDS.  Maurice spots a YELLOW WARBLER, a striking bird about eight inches long w vivid yellow feathers.  It sits elegantly on a nearby bra He walks towards it -- it stays in position.  Closer.  Th bird chirps back at him.  Maurice is within arms reach of bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen would have loved you. Maurice looks closer -- and notices it's wings.  The feat bend back -- a dark area at the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did that happen? Maurice watches the bird hop around the branch -- unable fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is a different color.  The refrigerator and appliances are brand new.  Ellen walks in -- something cradled in her hand.  Maurice looks up from his paper to Ellen move to the sink and lay a motionless bird on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaky voice) It must've hit the window... I think its neck is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bring it in here -- it probably has all kinds of diseases. Ellen finds an eye dropper from the table and fills it wi water -- she lets a few drops fall into the birds mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Evening, just before bed.  Maurice is reading.  Ellen is monitoring the bird closely.  It lays on the bedside tabl wrapped gently with a hand towel.  A morsel of food is lowered into its mouth with a pair of tweezers.  The bird stares blankly at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't going to make it Ellen. Let the poor thing go quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll make it. Her delicate hand rubs the bird's stomach.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The GRAPHIC IMAGES of the TV FLICKER on Maurice's face. glances back to Ellen who talks to the bird cradled in he arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You must miss flying.  Being way up there in the clouds looking down at all of us.  You miss that don't you?  You miss playing with your friends and talking with them... In the SOFT LIGHT of the lamp -- Ellen has transformed in mother rocking her child to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Maurice is reading his paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice!  Maurice!  Come out here. Maurice looks through the window to see Ellen waving to h frantically.

dialogues.speaker: BACKYARD
dialogues.text: Ellen points to the ground.  The little bird awkwardly wa around the porch. The bird's wings BURST into motion -- flapping hard -- catching the wind.  Ellen jumps up and down, bursting wit pride, as her little child takes flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. Ellen hugs Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he needed was love.  Once you have that, you can do anything. Young Maurice and Ellen watch the bird soar into the blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice is kneeling at a stream by the side of the road. gently clears away the dirt from the Yellow Warbler's feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be all right.  A couple days and you'll be up there again. Maurice carries the bird back to the trees.  He lays it b on the branch.  He stares at it's beautiful coat with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen would have loved you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelle is on the cordless.  Her fingers tapping on the kitchen table angrily.  Gerald moves around her as he set two plates at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I understand, it does sound humorous, but this is a very serious situation. Gerald is cooking.  He gently flips the chicken breast in butter and garlic sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This smells good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I such an authority?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Here comes the resume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I received my B.S. from the University of Pennsylvania, my P.H.D. from Bryn Mawr College.  I worked three years at the Boston University School of Medicine, during which time I had articles printed in the "Journal of Educational Psychology", "American Journal of Psychology", "Psychology Review" and "Science"... So I think it's safe to say my opinion is valid. Gerald brings the sizzling pan over and divides the steam dish into both plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, please find him for me... Officer, I tried... but I brought back the wrong person. Gerald quickly scoops some rice onto both plates.  His mo is watering as he goes for the utensils. Adelle abruptly stands at her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop laughing! Gerald gets into his seat at the table just in time to se Adelle angrily hang up the phone.  She stares off into sp before unconsciously cleaning the table.  Adelle picks up both plates of food...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelle -- Gerald's heart sinks as Adelle pops open the trash can wi tap of her foot and dumps the picture perfect meal into t garbage.  She goes to the sink and rinses the plates completely preoccupied with her thoughts.  She mumbles to herself as she shuts off the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he admires him. Adelle storms out of the kitchen.  Gerald sits at the emp table with a fork in his hands.  He shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The land is flat.  From the roads one can see endless fie in all directions.  When the wind blows, the crops bend i unison, changing the shape and texture of the land for a moment and instantly changing back with a snap of the win Maurice takes in the beauty of the land through a painful grimace.  Occasionally clutching his right leg in moments extreme pain. Maurice rests on an abandoned tractor by the side of the and watches the wind change the fields.  He closes his ja as the gusts become stronger.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL
dialogues.text: The clock clicks past 11:30 am.  Maurice is still in bed the curtains drawn.  He crawls out from under the sheets downs two pills with a glass of water.  He looks bad.  Hi face pale, his eyes at half-mast.  He wipes unnatural swe from his brow and melts into the bed again.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Just after dusk.  A small town's main road.  Maurice quie passes under the street lights. He stares up and tightens the hood on his parka as the fi SNOWFLAKE falls into the SHAFT OF THE STREET LIGHT.  Soon thousands of flakes fall into the light...

dialogues.speaker: GAZETTE BUILDING
dialogues.text: Kris fields calls frantically as the LIGHTS BLINK ANXIOUS on his phone.  The front page of the Gazette is posted on pin up board.  It reads... "HE MARCHES ON..."  Underneath A PICTURE of Maurice standing outside his bookstore holdi up THE BOOK SOCIETY MEDALLION proudly. A teenage boy gets off the elevator and maneuvers an enor bag over his shoulder... emblazoned across his back are t words "MAIL ROOM."  The boy comes to Kris and empties the on Kris' desk without a word.  Hundreds of letters cascad down swallowing the table top and covering Kris who stare awe as the letters keep coming.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL
dialogues.text: Maurice is COUGHING PAINFULLY.  He crouches over the edge the bed and holds his side with every strain. Maurice looks worse than ever.  His hair and shirt are so with sweat.  The coughing attack stops.  Maurice take a couple deep breaths before laying back down. His feet are visible -- sticking out from beneath the she They look like someone has beaten them with a stick, swol and bruised.  They disappear under the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: SNOW COVERED ROADS
dialogues.text: that stretch into a white oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning.  The branches of the trees are encapsulate ice.  The snow piled ten inches on every surface.  Mauric buried deep beneath three layers of clothes, looks around His breath materializes with every step.  He forces a wea smile at the magical landscape before him.  White.  Pure. Peaceful. The SOUNDS OF A VOLVO STATION WAGON urges Maurice to the of the road.  As it passes a little girl waves from the passenger window.  Maurice puts on a brave face and waves back. Another CAR ENTERS the picture -- A DARK BLUE FIREBIRD ri over the hill in the opposite lane moving fast, too fast. SLOW-MOTION as the Firebird skids over the ice and the sn -- the driver desperately trying to gain control... The mother in the Volvo hits the BRAKES as the Firebird spins into her lane... Maurice yells out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! The cars IMPACT with a sickening CRUNCH -- BACK TO REAL T The Firebird spins into a guardrail, breaking through it coming to a stop in a bank of snow. The Volvo isn't so lucky.  It flips from the impact... sliding on its roof, driving through the snow, down the road... It comes to a rest a hundred feet away. SILENCE.  STILLNESS.  The entire event took only seconds. Maurice runs frantically after the Volvo.  The windows ar SHATTERED.  Snow has packed into the over-turned car.  No can be seen inside the vehicle. Maurice kneels down and punctures the wall of snow with h hand.  His arm disappears up to the shoulder.  His face grimacing with the strain.  His arm comes out slowly... A few MUFFLED SOBS ARE HEARD BEFORE the little girl break through the wall of snow and slides out of the window.  S lets out a DESPERATE GASP for air as Maurice pulls her ou the wrist. Maurice clears her mouth and face and watches as she coug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panting) It's okay.  It's all over. Maurice lays her gently against a snow bank, before movin the other side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she okay? Maurice looks up to see the driver of the Firebird walkin towards him.  He looks dazed. Maurice doesn't waste another second and plunges his arm the snow... deeper than before.  His cheek pressed agains the snow, almost laying flat on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantic) Oh no... she's wearing a seat-belt. Maurice fishes around... his teeth clenched... He lets ou POWERFUL GRUNT as he pulls back with all his strength -- woman's WRIST appears first, then the tangled hair and th the body spills out onto the road next to Maurice. The driver appears over the Woman and Maurice and loses i when he sees them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault.  It wasn't my fault. Maurice, out of breath, clears the woman's face and mouth no movement.  No sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... please... Maurice holds her nose and breaths into her mouth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... She doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: A FRIGHTENING FLASH
dialogues.text: The mother's UNCONSCIOUS face turns into ELLEN.  Her life eyes -- her bruised cheek and forehead.  Her neck at an awkward angle.  Maurice stares down at his wife in horror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Ellen... don't die...

dialogues.speaker: THE MOTHER
dialogues.text: being revived by Maurice.  He pushes her chest in countin push, count, breath... push, count, breath... The mother's BODY TWITCHES, slightly at first -- then obviously... The mother let's out a FEW PAINFUL COUGHS. She takes a breath.  Life quickly returns to her body. Maurice places her head in his lap and hugs her, lightly rocking back and forth.  The tears streaming down his red face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's going to be fine Ellen.  I won't let anything happen to you.  I love you sweetie. Everything's going to be different now. The SCENE BACKS OUT as Maurice comforts this stranger in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police have descended on the scene.  Traffic has been blocked off in both directions.  The LIGHT thrown by the ambulances tints the snow and fields a THROBBING RED. Maurice's face can be seen in the shadows of the backseat a police car.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: OFFICER HANSEN AND OFFICER TANDY converse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Maurice.  He's dancing around everything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red flag, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's in trouble with the law -- fine.  Not our problem.  He yanked two people from a car wreck, let's give him some space. Hansen looks in at the drawn, exhausted face of Maurice through the window.  Hansen opens the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice, you need anything?  Which way were you headed?  We can drive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you officer.  I'll walk. Hansen throws a sharp glance to Tandy.  Hansen turns back Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grub?  Food?  How about food?  Our dime at the local diner... Maurice mulls this offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on man, you're a hero.  In Nebraska we don't let hero's walk around with empty stomachs. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I need to be brought back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The end of the meal.  Maurice sits in a booth across from Hansen and Tandy.  They watch as Maurice coughs violently into his napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like shit Maurice. Maurice takes a couple strained breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been footing it Maurice? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too long... (looks around) Excuse me gentlemen. Maurice gets up and heads to the bathroom.  Hansen and Ta stare at Maurice's shoulder bag laying on his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red flags man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not our problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why so vague?  Why so evasive?  He could be somebody hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not our problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to look beautiful when he turns out to be that animal who paid a visit to the Steadman's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's not a murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he is, half the town has seen us take him out for dinner like a couple of jack-asses. That makes Tandy think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's clean, he'll never know about it. Tandy looks to the men's bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it quick. Hansen instantly reaches over and begins rummaging throug the shoulder bag.  Hansen pulls out a little folder.  He opens the folder to reveal an old certificate.  Hansen sh Tandy the worn piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A marriage certificate?  Who the hell carries their marriage certificate around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice and Ellen Parker... it was issued in Philly... Mr. Maurice Parker has come a long way from home.  Why? Hansen returns the certificate and folder to the bag and leaves the booth quickly.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Maurice returns to the table to find only Tandy seated. Maurice sees Hansen in the phone booth at the far end of diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hansen's whipped.  Has to call his wife every two hours or she'll go ballistic when he gets home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P-A-R-K-E-R.  Right.  Get on the horn with Philly.  Call me here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Dally packs his things to leave.  He sees the li on LINE 1 LIGHT UP on his phone.  He ignores it.  The cle sticks her head around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Line one Sarg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here. Dally zips his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Nebraska state police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nebraska?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know somebody named -- Maurice Parker? Dally freezes.  He shakes his head as he unzips his jacke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) That son of a bitch made it to Nebraska. Dally grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The C.B. CRACKLES WITH THE VOICE OF SERGEANT DALLY AND TH NEBRASKA POLICE. MICHELLE, a very introverted intern, stares at the radio astonished.

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL SIDE OFFICE
dialogues.text: It now has "KRIS REDDY" etched on it's door.  Kris looks from his desk at Michelle who stands in the doorway brigh red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Michelle just points down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: Michelle scribbles down notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He saved a little girl, and her mother.  Pulled them right out of the car... Kris stands, jaw hanging wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? Michelle checks her notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very soft voice) Umm, Elm Creek, Nebraska. Kris practically falls over.  Michelle scribbles down mor quotes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This story is big huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mammoth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gazette's small huh? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?  This story is too big for this paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered again) Umm, no.  It's just that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn, you're right... You don't say much Michelle, but what you say is golden. Kris' mind is racing as the C.B. conversation continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hansen scoffs down his third dessert.  Maurice stares at oddly. The PAY PHONE RINGS.  Hansen jumps to his feet too quickl He tries to recover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too excited) I was expecting a call. Hansen moves to the phone. Tandy winks at Maurice with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whipped.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Hansen listens carefully to the officer on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'm on first name basis with half the city of Philadelphia... Hansen, apparently this guy Parker lost his wife and went a little fruity.  I spoke with his niece, Adelle Matlin and she says to restrain him.  That he's dangerous to himself.  She says to call when we have him in the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ride progresses in silence.  Hansen and Tandy in the front seat.  Maurice's head is pressed against the back-s window.  His eyes begin to shut slightly as sleep overcom him.  The car goes over a BUMP.  Maurice jars awake.  He glances out the window to see a highway sign swish by in HEADLIGHTS.  'ROUTE 80 EAST'. East?  Maurice looks around quickly at the passing scener

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me? Hansen and Tandy exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to drop off Tandy at the station and then drop you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Hansen looks back to the road.  The drive continues in silence.  Tandy checks his watch just when a CLICK -- A H WIND -- AND A METALLIC SLAM in quick succession shakes th car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that? Tandy looks back -- Maurice is GONE.  The back seat empty Tandy stares out the blackness of the back window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!  He jumped!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jumped where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the car.  He jumped out of the god damn car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice staggers through the naked trees.  Thin trees eve few feet with no branches.  The snow ankle deep. Maurice braces himself against a trunk, checking his hand His vision blurs as he stares down at his scraped bloody palms. The forest clears quickly into an open field.  Far in the distance across the field of white is a small pointed building standing alone.  The glow of a LIGHT can be seen through the windows. Maurice trudges through the deeper snow.  Stumbling many times.  The frigid wind pushing him to his knees.  Mauric keeps moving -- the field seems endless...

dialogues.speaker: DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Maurice's feet hit the snow of the driveway, just as his buckle -- his face HITS the snow hard.  He manages to rol over on his back with great effort.  He stares up at the pointed building -- the dull light becoming duller... something blocks the light.  A man.  Maurice feels himsel rise into the air as two powerful arms scoop him off the A PRIEST carries him into the doors of a CHURCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dimly lit cathedral.  Six foot six, FATHER BERCHMAN wal down the center isle of the cathedral, through a cloth curtain and into a

dialogues.speaker: BACK ROOM
dialogues.text: where Maurice is sitting in a chair wrapped in a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had seen you.  By the way I'm sorry about your wife.  They told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you... I'm sorry you had to lie.  It must have been difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked the officers if you had committed some crime... If they had said 'yes', you would be speaking with them right now. This is the father's own room.  Very sparse as one would expect.  He moves to his bureau and retrieves some pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take these, and if you're up to it, try to explain how it is you came to be sitting here. Maurice follows the father's instructions and tightens th blanket around his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm walking for my wife. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacifica, California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Beat.  The father nods as if this is not shocking news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe a person's soul lives on after their death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that that soul takes part of the person they were on this earth with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a reasonable assumption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want my wife's soul having any doubts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doubts?  About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About my love for her. The father nods with understanding as if everything becam very clear with that statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to prove anything to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not proving to her.  I'm showing her.  And I know I don't have to.  I want to.  I've realized, love is about giving. I'm alive, I can still give to her. I want to give her everything I can. The father studies this stranger before him with great admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some people, including those officers, that are trying to stop me.  They mean well.  But they don't understand.  I wouldn't either if I were them. Maurice struggles with the last words.  He slumps back -- physically drained. The father gets up and takes the empty glass of water fro Maurice's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to stay here a few days until you're better.  You're no use to your wife in this condition. The father moves for the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm crazy too. The father turns and smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have spent my life dedicated to love.  Love of God.  Love of humanity.  And here you are living through love.  Bathing in it. Using its strength, its magic, its ability to overcome any barrier... If you are crazy, I hope my insanity is not far off. Maurice's eyes well up instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Berchman wraps one powerful hand around a tiny sil cross dangling from his neck.  The other hand waves high the air at the shrinking figure of Maurice Parker walking through the snow.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: The long trek continues.  The black tar of the roads peek in spots as the SUN BEATS down on the flatlands.  Maurice drapes his worn scarf around a melting snowman.

dialogues.speaker: RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: We are looking inside a fancy Center-City Philadelphia restaurant.  Adelle and Gerald are seated by an enormous window.  A waiter comes to their table with their main course.  Gerald watches the food being served with great anticipation. Gerald's eyes drift out the window to the magazine stand the sidewalk... He squints to see better.  Realization hi hard... His eyes light up.  He looks to Adelle and back t the magazine stand. In a mad race for time, Gerald begins to devour the food his plate.  The waiter and Adelle watch him in shock.  Ad glances out the window.  Her eyes squint... then light up She jumps to her feet and grabs Gerald by the arm, a fork full of food drops to his plate.  Gerald looks back at hi full plate longingly as Adelle pulls him out of the restaurant. The waiter looks out the window to the magazine stand.  H squints.

dialogues.speaker: MAGAZINE STAND
dialogues.text: The NEW YORK TIMES are hung like stockings around the bor of the stand.  On the front pages, a singular headline st out among the others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large PHOTO OF MAURICE is next to the headline.

dialogues.speaker: DINER
dialogues.text: A red-headed waitress slices a credit card through the machine and waits... Green computer letters blink - "This account has been closed." The waitress returns with the card -- she shakes her head "No" at Maurice who digs into his wallet for cash.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL
dialogues.text: Maurice slides two twenties across the counter to the mot manager.  Maurice checks the remaining bills in his walle only a few bills left. In the motel room we find Maurice sitting over the edge o bed buckled over in a coughing attack.  It finally stops. Maurice flops back to the pillows, completely drained.

dialogues.speaker: ROADS
dialogues.text: The flatlands have vanished.  The roads now serpentine through mountain ranges. VIEW FROM THE MOUNTAIN RANGE; Maurice moves like a grain dust over the black line of the road. Maurice rests every half mile.  He labors up every inclin with ultimate effort.  He braces himself with a branch serving as a make due crutch. Maurice spots a small town nestled in the arms of the mountain range.  He begins the journey to rest.

dialogues.speaker: GROCERIES
dialogues.text: Maurice pays for his food with the last few bills in his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Another stick serves as a walking cane.  The multi layers clothes have been shed for a short-sleeve shirt.  Maurice follows a dirt road that breaks free of the mountains and into the open country again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dust covered mailbox at the end of a long dirt driveway Maurice wipes the mailbox clean with his hand.  The name emerges like an ancient inscription from beneath the mud.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Maurice tentatively moving to the front door.  His hand instinctively clutches his empty stomach. The wind blows gently.  Maurice shuts his eyes and takes deep breath.  He opens his eyes slowly to see a dinner ta being set.  Potatoes, gravy, fresh baked bread... floatin through the half open window to Maurice's thankful smile. THE SOUNDS OF CHILDREN AND ADULTS CAN BE HEARD INSIDE. The first LIGHT KNOCKS go unheard with all the commotion. HARDER.  The door squeaks open.  Maurice puts on his best smile... the door opens wider -- no one stands before him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Maurice looks down to find an adorable little boy, black hair, big eyes and an even bigger grin.  This is three ye old ISAAC CALDWELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Isaac... I'm three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Maurice Parker... I'm much older than three.  Are your parents home? Beat.  Isaac thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, I can play baseball with my brothers when I'm bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what... I'm just little now, but I'll be big soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll probably be bigger than your brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! Isaac is happy with this thought. Maurice looks up as MRS. CALDWELL comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to Isaac? Mrs. Caldwell stops as she stares at Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Maurice Parker.  I'm just passing through and I need to conserve what little funds I have... I need some food and a roof to sleep under for one night... Now I don't look like much, but if there are any things that need to get done around the house -- Mrs. Caldwell doesn't listen, but instead yells behind th door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave... you're not going to believe who's here. Maurice looks at her oddly.  MR. CALDWELL comes to the do his face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Maurice Parker -- the one walking for his wife. Mr. Caldwell is completely floored.  So, for that matter Maurice.  Mr. Caldwell puts out his hand with awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that ain't fate?... Hi, I'm Dave Caldwell.  I do the copy for the anchor on the evening news down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening News?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did a piece after your story ran in the New York Times. Maurice is truly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York Times? Mrs. Caldwell ushers Maurice in the doorway by the elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone said they spotted you in town... Mr. Parker, you're a celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caldwell family dinner... all twelve of them.  Ten children talk and reach for food.  Maurice sits at the en talking, enjoying and sharing.  Isaac sits next to him proudly.  Maurice has blended in as another member of thi family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An inviting room.  The kind prepared for visiting grandmothers and grandfathers to stay in. Maurice checks himself out in the mirror... his borrowed pajamas fit nicely. He moves to the window and stares at the moon lit landscape... enormous, endless, dwarfing. The rocking chair CREAKS as Maurice melts into it.  He ru his calves slowly, the pain evident in his face.  His hea leans back after a moment... on the verge of sleep. The SOUND OF TINY FOOTSTEPS stirs him.  He looks to the doorway to find Isaac standing quietly at the door in his baseball P.J.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what... I remembered you were here and I woke up. Isaac walks silently to Maurice... Tip-toeing all the way

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your parents would want you to be in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell stories?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no... I'm not good at that. Very bad in fact... Too late.  Isaac climbs up into Maurice's lap with great effort.  Maurice looks down at Isaac who waits patiently him to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would be exceedingly boring. Isaac waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do these type of things. Isaac -- still waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See there are two kinds of people in this world. (beat) ... Just a short one okay? Isaac gets in position, cradled in Maurice's arms.  Mauri searches for something to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a boy named Isaac who wanted to play baseball, but he was too small and no one would let him play... but he kept practicing by himself -- waiting... He went to every game and sat in the stands with his glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what... maybe I ran onto the field and hit a home run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's telling this story? Isaac points to Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, now the team had this great big player -- Big Billy.  He was the best.  He had them in the World Super-Bowl-Championship of little kids baseball.  But right before the game, the second best player on the team was suspended because he played a prank on a nice man who owned a book store... When that boy grew up he was convicted on burglary charges and spent fifteen years in prison -- where he belongs. Isaac didn't understand that last part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, Big Billy needed another player so he yelled into the stands.  'Who can play baseball?' And there was a little voice that yelled out, 'Me, I can play.' Everyone turned to see a little boy standing with a glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  But everyone saw how small Isaac was and laughed... but not Big Billy.  He stared at Isaac carefully and then told him to join the game.  It came to the end of the game.  It was the eleventh or twelfth inning or whatever is the last inning of a game...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay nine.  Big Billy's team was losing and he was on base.  That's when Isaac came up.  He could barely hold the bat... Big Billy winked at Isaac... The ball was pitched -- Isaac hit the ball hard. It soared up and out over the stadium.  Everyone cheered.  Isaac hit a home run and won the game. After the game, Isaac asked Big Billy why he let he play.  Big Billy smiled and said, I wasn't always Big Billy, I was Little Billy first... Isaac and Big Billy went off after the game and read a classic book together.  The end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what -- that was a really good story... Tell it again. Maurice has to smile as Isaac looks up anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a boy named Isaac who liked to play baseball... WE BACK OUT as Maurice rocks back and forth in his chair. Isaac falling asleep in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family dog "Max", scurries up and down with great excitement.  Max can sense something big is happening. The Caldwell clan, one and all has gathered at the end of their driveway.  Maurice is escorted out by Isaac who cli tightly to his hand.  Mr. Caldwell meets Maurice halfway pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice watch. Maurice looks down at his beat-up Seiko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted a watch like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unstrapping it) It's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I won't take it unless I pay for it... Let's see, that's a pretty nice watch -- I can see that. Maurice watches him suspiciously as he pulls out an envel from his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say I give you what's in this envelope for that beautiful watch. Maurice is handed the envelope.  He opens it to find a th PILE OF CASH, TENS AND TWENTIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really want that watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my only chance to get a watch like that.  It would mean a lot to me and my family.  Please take it.  It really isn't that much. Maurice stares into the envelope emotionally and hands ov the watch tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a loan. Mr. Caldwell straps on the watch and then hugs Maurice. The rest of the family say their good-byes. Isaac won't let go of Maurice's hand as he walks out into street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac, come back here. Isaac just holds on tighter.  After Maurice and Isaac hav walked a few steps out into the street, Maurice kneels do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go now. Isaac's bottom lip protrudes as he tries not to cry.  Mau has to hold back a few tears himself.  He hugs Isaac tigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Why didn't I meet you fifteen years ago? Maurice pulls away from Isaac slowly.  Isaac runs to his mother's arms.  Maurice waves good-bye to the Caldwells a heads down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice stops, bends down to the road and picks up a TORN WHITE PAPER STREAMER that spiraled its way to his feet. He looks ahead and finds both sides of the street lined w parked cars.  Some of the cars are decorated with white streamers.

dialogues.speaker: OUTDOOR WEDDING
dialogues.text: A beautiful canopy of flowers sits at the end of ten rows lawn chairs.  Maurice watches from near the cars.  He smi as the young bride and groom nervously say their vows. Everyone LAUGHS warmly as the groom stumbles over his lin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments before the ceremony.  The guests are seated.  The ORGAN is PLAYING.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE ROOM
dialogues.text: Young Maurice sits on a chair in a tuxedo staring out the half-open door to an OLD MAN who tries to gain his balanc holding onto the wall.  Maurice is upset.  He runs his fingers through his hair. THE DOOR OPENS wide as Young Ellen comes in.  She is wear her WEDDING GOWN.  White lace, tight at the arms and wais she looks stunning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?  They said something was wrong? Maurice stares at his rented shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Ellen moves to him and kneels before him.  She lifts his chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's here.  Everything looks beautiful.  They even got the white dove I wanted for the cake -- so what's wrong?  What is it? Maurice moves his gaze from her to the half open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him. Ellen looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's plastered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay -- really it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not.  He should be here with me now, not trying to find some fucking bottle of Johnny Walker.  He's never been there for me.  I've always been alone. Maurice looks like he may cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Ellen... I'm scared of being alone again.  What if one day you realize how boring I am?  What if one day you realize you're not happy? (beat) I could have been alone before, but now you've changed things.  I can't be alone anymore Ellen.  I'm scared what's going to happen to me. Ellen takes both his hands and squeezes them between hers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day I met you, I gave you my heart.  Today, I give you my soul. Where ever you are, where ever you go, I will be with you.  Maurice Parker, I promise -- (she shakes him with emphasis) I promise, you will never be alone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bride and groom run through a shower of rice into the limousine.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE LIMOUSINE
dialogues.text: They wave through the window as the car pulls away.  They settle in and look to the seat across from them.  On the is a fresh flower.  Next to the flower is a note.  The gr picks it up and shows it to the bride.  It reads:

dialogues.speaker: "CHERISH EVERYDAY TOGETHER"
dialogues.text: It is signed "M.P." The bride and groom look at each other curiously.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The limousine passes Maurice on the road as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fax machine rolls out a tongue of information.  Michell the intern, snatches it and jogs through the maze of desk

dialogues.speaker: KRIS'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Michelle catches the tail end of a telephone conversation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Come on Pete, this is important, this is racism in our backyard... Aw, that's bull... just think about it, okay? Kris hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're pushing my Jewish temple vandalism story to the Metro section... Kris notices Michelle's familiar bright red face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Michelle is completely flustered as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle, breathe... that's it, what is it, talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands the fax over) Umm, Coalville Utah. Kris studies the fax before jumping up from his desk and moving to the wall.  An enormous U.S. MAP covers three quarters of the wall.  RED TACKS mark a trail across the United States, beginning with Philadelphia.  Kris puts a tack at the top right corner of Utah. Kris notices through the open officer door that Frank and Seth are listening in.  Kris nods to Michelle.  Who immediately shuts the door on their view.  Kris waves bye before it closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's taking highway 80 all the way. Kris paces the room -- charged with excitement -- eyes occasionally stopping on the map.  Michelle watches Kris' animated expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this is, don't you? It's a miracle.  Not like... 'It was a miracle little Johnny passed his math test.'  No!  This is a real miracle... Turning water to wine kind of miracle.  People should know about this, everyone, every single person... It's time for a blitz.  Let's see what kind of TV interest we can generate. Michelle enjoys watching Kris when he's like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm, he's going to make it isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. Kris studies the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he hasn't hit the toughest miles yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are out.  The FLICKER FROM THE TV dances over Adelle and Gerald.  Adelle is fast asleep.  Gerald is hav a late night sandwich.  NIGHTLINE comes on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you do for love?  This is the question Americans are starting to ask themselves.  The incredible tale of Maurice Parker's walk across the country has caught the imaginations of young and old. Gerald sighs.  He puts the sandwich on the plate and hand to his left -- obediently.  PAN TO LEFT to find Adelle wi awake now.  She glares at the TV screen silently as she t the sandwich and dumps it in the waste basket releasing s of her frustration. A COMPUTER MAP OF THE U.S. trails Maurice's walk on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 44, this bookstore owner from Wynnewood Pennsylvania has tallied an estimated 2,400 miles.  His latest appearance in Coalville Utah brought the spotlight of the country to that small town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coalville Utah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever has carried Mr. Parker through snow and rain and thousands of miles of this countryside, will have to carry him through the most dangerous part of his trek... The three hundred miles through the sweltering roads of Nevada...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A merciless sun beats down on a long stretch of highway. black tar from the road melting slightly. No sign of Maurice.  WE SEE into the distance, not a soul sight.  WE LOOK to a hillside a hundred meters from the r There we see a figure lying still in the shade of an overhanging rock formation. Maurice has a towel over his eyes and his feet propped up his shoulder bag.  He is fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: DUSK
dialogues.text: The SUN TURNS RED for one brilliant moment before hiding behind the horizon.  Like an alarm went off, Maurice wake and packs his things.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The MOONLIGHT outlines a line figure hobbling his way ste step with a walking stick. The air fills with a POWERFUL RUMBLE.  Maurice turns to s wave of rocks and sand slide down a hillside to the road. They CAUSE A GREAT THUNDER that settles to dust.  Maurice walks down the center of the highway away from the hillsi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FIERY NEVADA SUN BEGINS ITS ASCENT INTO THE SKY.  Mau looks bad.  He's breathing heavy as he moves up a steep incline by the side of the road.  His feet slide on the l dirt.  Maurice looks like he could collapse at any moment He makes it to the indentation in the hillside -- just en room to lay down in the shade.  Maurice lays out slowly. pries off his sneakers, band-aids and blisters cover ever inch of his feet.  Maurice dumps the sand out of his snea and painfully pulls them back on.  His eyes close as he t to unbutton his jacket... too late he's asleep. Maurice's bed is a rock that juts from the side of the hill... First WE SEE nothing, then some grains of sand es from the crack where the rock meets the hillside.  The CR

dialogues.speaker: BECOMES SLIGHTLY LARGER
dialogues.text: FRACTION OF AN INCH.  It stabilizes there. Maurice unaware of his precarious situation sleeps twenty five feet above the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MID-DAY
dialogues.text: Another sizzler.  Temperatures in the nineties.  The sun directly overhead. Maurice stirs in his sleep, moving closer to the edge of rock. A STEADY STREAM OF SAND POURS FROM THE CRACK... A SLIGHT TREMOR... THEN THE FRIGHTENING SOUND OF ROCK MOVING AGAINST ROCK... Maurice wakes up as he begins to slide off... Hands scrap at the dirt... He SLIDES OFF THE ROCK... Feet and hands desperately trying to cling to the hillside... He picks u speed as he tumbles down... Maurice looks down in time to a small jut in the rock hurtling towards him... no time f panic... SLAM!  A SICKENING CRACK OF BONE as Maurice HITS rock square in the ribs... Maurice flops down the rest of slope like a rag doll... he comes to rest in the dirt, clutching his ribs.  The sun beats down on his stunned ey Maurice stares up at the dizzying slope.  Sand still trickling down to a stop.  He doesn't try to move for the first few seconds.  His breathing increasingly erratic. Maurice drags himself to sit upright.  The sharp pains causing a distorted grimace on his face.  A short rest, before working his way to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Maurice uses a highway guardrail as a backrest.  He takes seat in the dirt.  Maurice's hair is damp with sweat.  Hi breathing relegated to slow gasps.  His left hand coverin his rib cage protectively.  Blood begins to trickle throu the spaces between his fingers. Maurice closes his eyes for a moment, before his bent leg goes into spasms... Maurice is forced to straighten the l instantly... jarring his tender rib cafe... Maurice cling the back of his thigh... Maurice is defeated... On the ve of tears. He glances way down the road and spots a TINY CLOUD OF SM miles away in the distance.  A car is moving in his direction. Maurice looks up into the DAZZLING WHITE SKY.  Drops of s falling into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper) It's over Ellen... I failed you again. Maurice looks down the road at the cloud of dust growing larger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried Ellen, I really tried... I don't have the strength. The cloud is now clearly a car... Maurice stares up into sky again... The tears racing the sweat down his cheeks. Maurice YELLS TO THE HEAVENS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I would never be alone!... You promised... (his yelling turns to sobs) ... You promised. Maurice's is interrupted by A SLIGHT RUSTLING BEHIND HIS HEAD.  Maurice turns and looks through his tears... There, a few feet from him, perched quietly and majestica on the guardrail is a GOLDEN EAGLE.  It stands two and ha feet tall.  It spreads it's great wings.  The feathers ex like a blanket, spanning six feet, and throwing a gentle shade on Maurice's face. Maurice is frozen in wonder.  The MAGIC of the moment glo in his eyes.  Maurice's face gains life... The dark feath eagle stands like a god before Maurice.  The moment is breathtaking.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The car on the road, takes the last quarter mile in seconds... SCREECHING IT'S BRAKES at the sight of Maurice the side of the road. Maurice turns away from the bird as the car pulls up.  Th driver gets out and calls over the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man are you okay? Maurice's face filled with strength.  He grins through th pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing out here?  You need a ride somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. The driver is concerned.  He opens the driver door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You by yourself? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This pacifies the driver somewhat.  He nods and gets in t car.  Maurice watches as the car pulls away. He turns back to the guardrail -- the eagle is gone.  Mau looks up into the sky.  The Golden Eagle is flying overhead... a tiny dot against the blazing sun. Maurice struggles to his feet using the guardrail as supp Maurice takes his first step...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suburbia.  Rows of similar houses with small lawns and cu mailboxes.  Beautiful trees line the streets creating a canopy over the roadway. Two women sit on a swing on the front porch of a small suburban home.  JANIS AND AMMIE'S conversation is cut in sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  What's the matter with him? Janis and Ammie stare to the street where a sunburnt MAUR staggers in a daze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice is on the edge of darkness... the trees and faces swimming -- mixed with the colors of red and blue cloth waving in the wind... Images come in and out of focus... women walking towards him... Maurice clutches his head as trees start to swim faster -- color, lights, houses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice collapses in the middle of this suburban street. Janis and Ammie run to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice lays still on a hospital bed.  His eyes slowly fo themselves open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning Mr. Parker. Maurice turns his head to the side.  A pretty woman in he late twenties, with LARGE LOCKS OF BROWN HAIR smiles back This is STEPHANIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a lot of people worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which hospital?  Did you take me back? Stephanie understands his worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in St. Vincent's Hospital in Roseville California.  You've been here three days. Maurice closes his eyes in relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is crowded.  Maurice is now propped up in a seat position.  He tries to digest a set of fish sticks on a t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you're here.  I'm touched. Maurice looks across to ADELLE AND GERALD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you two planning kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should definitely have children.  They're really special. Adelle and Gerald are in shock.  Maurice forks another fi stick with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you realize how serious this is Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How serious is it? DR. RAY, who has been standing by the window listening, s forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have two broken ribs, a punctured spleen and Acute Rheumatoid Arthritis. Maurice gives a comforting smile to Adelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The normal amount of build up in your arteries has been aggravated by over exertion.  This is called, "Claudication,"  As a result, there isn't enough circulation to your body.  That accounts for the discoloration in your extremities and the muscle spasms I'm sure you've encountered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can, but it'll have to wait in line. This surprises Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran a C.T. and an M.R.I.  We found bleeding in your brain.  Your collapse was caused by "Transient Cerebral-Ischemia"... a sudden loss of blood circulation to the brain. In other words, Mr. Parker, you had a mild stroke. There is dead silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared) I suppose I over did it. Adelle moves over to Maurice's side and holds his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What steps do we take now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We operate.  We find the artery in the brain and close the bleeding... I just did this procedure on a Senator and he's doing fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the odds?  Do I have a fifty-fifty chance of surviving the operation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to say.  It's a delicate surgery.  There's no getting around the fact that it's a very high-risk situation. Adelle strokes Maurice's hair.  Maurice stares down at hi food before looking up with great resolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it'll have to wait until I finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finish the walk, and then we may take all the chances we want. The room is stunned.  Adelle gets off the bed and collect herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me very carefully, because I don't want you to misunderstand me... The walk is over Uncle Maurice.  Done. Finished.  You've made it to California, it was a miracle, now let's try to save your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) I'm completing the walk.  I'm almost there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Maurice keep it calm... (beat) We can talk about this again, but just so you know, we have a guard on this floor who's sole job it is to keep an eye on you. Maurice is crushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a lot of people out there who would like to see you finish, including me, but I'm not willing to put your life in anymore risk than it is... We do the operation, and when you're better, you finish the walk. The room is dead again.  Maurice drowns in his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small chapel.  Stain glass windows overlooking the park lot.  Maurice sits in his wheel chair at the back of the room.  A few other patients are scattered in the four sma pews. Maurice has his hands folded tightly and stares up at the statue of Mary.  His concentration is broken as a man in full black suit and black shirt sits next to him.  Mauric nods at the priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused.  I'm not sure what to do now.  I'm not sure what he wants for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to reward you... That's why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little confused) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean you've done a great thing. You should be rewarded monetarily. Maurice is lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your shoe size?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Who are you? The priest reaches into his jacket -- for the first time SEE a Polo design on his shirt and a gaudy gold chain aro his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive Silver -- Marketing Executive at Reebok. Maurice stares at the card in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you to do some spots for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? Some of the patients turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking six figures, pay or play -- for two spots.  We want to push a new line with you... America's New Hero. Maurice is flustered.  He can't take this.  His eyes beco desperate. Clive waves his hands in the air excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine grainy black and white shots of long stretches of highway -- quick cuts with a slow pounding beat underneath... Then we see a man walking up a steep incline -- it's you Maurice.  We see shots of you walking.  Cut.  Cut.  Cut. Fast... Music crescendoes -- Bham! Close up -- and you say... 'Reebok, Because There's Nothing You Can't Do.' Clive finishes.  He is surprised to find Maurice in tears Clive is thrown totally off as Maurice stares at him angr through streaming tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is dead. Maurice continues his powerful gaze until Clive looks awa Clive gathers his things and leaves the chapel without another word.  Maurice drops his head into his hands and cries quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A change of shifts.  Stephanie gathers her things.  She l her coat off the counter.  Underneath is a paper.  She sp the paper to face her.  The headline reads, "The End of a Journey - Parker Hospitalized."

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: Stephanie peeks into the dark room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Good night Mr. Parker.  I'll see you tomorrow. Stephanie waits for a response from the motionless figure the bed.  She leaves the room a little disappointed. WE MOVE CLOSER TO THE BED.  We see Maurice laying still - the battered photo of Ellen clutches to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie is wheeling Maurice down the hall.  Maurice has glint of happiness in his eye.  They move through the doo marked "Visitor's Area." Maurice stretches a huge grin as KRIS REDDY gets up from chair.  Kris bends down and hugs Maurice emotionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Joad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The Grapes of Wrath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're amazing.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Maurice and Kris seated in the corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed you Kris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed you to Mr. Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelle told me, your writing is going well.  The Crusader for social issues and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right.  From the heart is always better. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drove by the bookstore -- it's boarded up now.  There's a sign over the wood -- "Office space available." The loss is evident on Maurice's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been too punctual with the rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking you could open another store with investors.  I'm sure a lot of people would want to get involved with you now. Maurice forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm not worried about my career right now... I'm more worried about how you're getting me out of here? Beat.  Kris glances at the hair on his forearm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they standing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running his hand over his arm) Saluting. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Mr. Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, come on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it.  I want you to finish, but I want you to live more. Maurice sits back straight.  He looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do the operation after I finish. I can't risk not finishing... I thought you understood what I was doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why in God's name did you fly all the way here then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... To look me in the eye and say what's important to you isn't as important to me?  To tell me you know what's best?  To tell me life is more precious than what I feel for my wife? Kris gets very emotional.  He rises from this chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker, you can yell at me, if it'll help.  But I'm not risking your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mine to risk. Maurice turns to the window away from Kris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your operation is scheduled for Friday.  I'll be back before then. Kris walks to the door and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows you love her Mr. Parker. She knows now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at Kris) No more words.  Until I touch the ocean with my hands... it's all just words. Kris is tortured.  He leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice wheels himself into the hall from the waiting are He looks around.  His eyes lock on the EXIT SIGN over the door at the end of the hall.  His eyes scan the area quic He immediately finds the guard on the floor staring at hi The guard nods ever so slightly as if to say, "I know wha you're thinking."  Maurice turns his attention to a small in a hospital gown, being scolded by a head nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cooperate with us about taking your medicine and maybe we'll talk about candy. The head nurse takes a chocolate bar out of the boy's tin hands.  The boy offers no response.  Maurice watches curiously as STEPHANIE walks over and pats the boys head. Maurice catches a small exchange -- Stephanie slips anoth candy bar into his pocket.  The boy breaks into a warm sm Stephanie puts her fingers against her lips and winks. Maurice takes this exchange in with great interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie steps into the room and prepares a tray of food The SILHOUETTED FIGURE of Maurice seated near the bay win turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be in bed. The face stares back from the shadows.  She feels him watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do your friends call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a car, Steph? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be in bed... Stephanie moves to Maurice... She stops short when his fa comes into view.  His eyes are raw -- red.  His face puff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They told me, you might try to talk me into something... You need to rest Mr. Parker... It's for your own good. (beat) I've been following your story for a long while.  It's a beautiful thing you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever lose somebody Stephanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker, I'm supposed to give you your fish sticks. Beat.  Maurice melts her with his expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... My father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell him everything you wanted to?  Did you do everything you could while he was here? She shakes her head "No" -- the tears welling up in her e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't do this Steph, my life isn't worth saving. Maurice reaches out and squeezes her soft trembling hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie throws a nervous smile to the guard as she esco a doctor down the hall... The doctor's oversized while la coat almost drags on the floor as he tries to hide the pa of being on his feet.  MAURICE PARKER studies a bogus cha in his hands.  His new glasses, sliding off his nose.  Be of sweat -- revealing his agony.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Three people in the elevator; Stephanie, Dr. Maurice Park and a female physician.  The female doctor looks at Mauri curiously, studying his demeanor -- she can't place him. The ELEVATOR DOORS OPEN on the third floor... The SOUND O TV FLOODS THE ELEVATOR COMPARTMENT.  Maurice looks up in horror to see a close-up of his FACE superimposed on the screen seated on the receptionist's desk.  A man gets on elevator. The female doctor stares at the TV as the doors close -- immediately turns to Maurice... her view is blocked by th new passenger... the elevator progresses down 2... 1... The female doctor leans forward trying to get a glimpse o Maurice... THE BELL DINGS as the doors open on the ground floor. Doctor Maurice Parker and Stephanie quickly exit... the female doctor stays in the elevator and watches carefully

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells) Excuse me, doctor... DOWN THE HALL... Maurice pauses and turns around -- fear etched across his face.  The female doctor looks around t barren hall then turns back to Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. The female doctor smiles as the doors shut.  After a few moments of shock -- Maurice smiles back. Stephanie yanks Maurice down the hall and out the EMERGEN ROOM EXIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A colorful canopy of leaves... a familiar torn American f Stephanie's white VW Rabbit pulls to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it... This is where I fell. He turns back to Stephanie who stares back at him emotionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thanked my father.  He did so much for me... I never thanked him. Maurice holds her sad face in his scared hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) It's not too late. Maurice gets out of the car painfully slow.  He pulls his shoulder back upright with a laborious breath.  A sense o pride returns to his face.  He turns back to Stephanie an catches a horrified look.  He follows her stare... She is staring at his shirt... He looks down to see a DAR CRIMSON STAIN GROWING beneath the surface.  He covers the area with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have a lot of work to do when I get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone should be with you. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is. He gives her his best smile and begins shuffling his feet over the loose gravel of the road... one step at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black man -- grey, balding hair walks hurriedly up the stairs.  This is STAN NEWTON. Keeping in step with Newton is a police officer.  SERGEAN EMORY, jet white hair, army cut, gives him an intimidatin appearance.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE DOOR
dialogues.text: Newton stops Emory before entering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Mrs. Matlin is very upset. Emory lets the warning sink in before opening the door. Adelle's VOICE IS BOOMING.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: Adelle YELLS at Dr. Ray, a few nurses, and the guard who on duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... "American Journal of Psychology", "Psychological Review", and "Science", so I think it's safe to say my opinion is valid. She catches her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does a grown man who can barely walk, just stroll out?... This is not James Bond here, this is my uncle who owns a bookstore, and gets outwitted by grade school kids pulling pranks! Adelle notices the new people in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Matlin, this is Sergeant Emory.  He'll help us find your uncle. Adelle walks up to Emory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you a story Sergeant. There was a patient of mine who had a Golden Retriever, Mac... She loved Mac, not like a pet, but like a family member.  One day, she had to leave Mac with 'friends', and wouldn't you know it, Mac gets away and ends up falling into a sewer. My patient comes back -- goes nuts when she hears that Mac has been in the sewer for over 48 hours. Apparently the cop who found the dog didn't want to get his pants dirty.  And neither did anyone else.  So of course, my patient decides to go in after it... she falls... breaks her hip and lands next to her dead dog, who died of toxic fumes down there... Adelle looks around at all the engrossed faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moral of the story is... She sued for a lot of money!  She sued the friends, the city, and the officer for negligence on duty. She has no Mac, no happiness, but she's very rich now... That was a dog.  We're talking about a human being... (beat) I hope everyone clearly understands the chain of events that will occur if something should happen to my uncle, whom I love more than you can possibly imagine... Now Sergeant I would like to know right now, if you're willing to get your pants dirty for my uncle? Adelle and Emory have a staring contest.  Adelle wins. Adelle stands alone in a room with four men, and she is clearly the one in charge. The door flies open.  A police officer walks in pushing K REDDY through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found him sneaking up the back stairs with this. The officer holds out a long coat and hat.  Emory walks u Kris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you help Mr. Parker leave this hospital? Kris looks to the empty bed and smiles... a BIG SMILE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... But I was going to. Beat.  Emory turns to the officer and ushers him to the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget him.  It's time to get our pants dirty. Adelle smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want three black and whites from here to Handley Avenue.  And no communication with the station. The press monitors the transmissions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a born actor) They can do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goes for all of you.  Not a word about this disappearance to anyone.  Absolutely no press. Kris smiles innocently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police vehicles roam the city streets -- slowing to a cra at every white male over forty, walking the sidewalks.

dialogues.speaker: ADELLE
dialogues.text: scanning the crowded intersections through the open windo her moving taxi.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: patrolling the streets on foot.  He stops at a hot dog ve and flashes a picture of Maurice from his wallet.  The ve shakes his head, "No." A COMMOTION BREAKS OUT ONE BLOCK DOWN... Kris spins in th direction... sees a crowd forming at the corner of the sidewalk... Starts toward them... Kris sees something thr the thinner parts of the crowd... something laying on the sidewalk... A man!  Kris' walk turns into a sprint. Kris works his way through the growing crowd, puncturing center of the circle... Kris gazes down at the man writhi on the concrete... A black man, shaking uncontrollably. women standing over the fallen man waves the crowd back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has Epilepsy, just give him room... An ambulance is on the way. The crowd spreads out.  Kris looks down at the unconsciou man on the sidewalk sadly -- Kris' thoughts race.  He mov on with newfound concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A converted gymnasium.  The room is splintered into rows folding tables and chairs.  Against the wall, is the serv stand.  Groups of volunteers dispense sandwiches and soup

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CORNER
dialogues.text: The room is crowded with homeless men and women and a few children.  In the back we find MAURICE.  In his old cloth and tired disheveled appearance -- Maurice is virtually invisible in this crowd.  He presses something to his inj side.  His condition has worsened. He eyes the entrance where a POLICE OFFICER walks in and moves to the serving counter.  The officer asks the servi lady something, and shows her a picture.  She shrugs her shoulders and continues serving.  The cop takes one last around the hundreds of hungry people leaving the room. Maurice pulls up his hand from underneath his shirt.  The napkin he was holding at his side is SATURATED WITH BLOOD Maurice replaces it with a clean napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emory rubs his eyes as the papers pile up on his desk. OFFICER KLEIN lays out the newspapers one after the other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... L.A. Times -- 'He's Back.'... San Francisco Chronicle -- 'Have You Seen Maurice?'... New York Post 'Unstoppable!' Klein lays the last paper on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  The Mayor sent word, that he wants this thing handled quickly, before anything unfortunate happens.  He said he doesn't want to be known as the 'Mayor of the City Where Maurice Parker Died!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Mrs. Matlin's waiting for you. Klein opens the door.  Adelle walks in and stands at a distance from Emory.  She looks beat.  Her eyes are bloodshot, and tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened with the museum sighting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: False alarm. Adelle is visibly dejected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long couple of days for all of us.  So let me be honest. If he hasn't turned up yet, he's probably --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke with Dr. Ray this morning, and he said it was highly unlikely that someone in his condition could survive this long without medical attention, let alone walk sixty miles -- in fact his exact word was, 'Impossible'. Adelle fiddles with her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I knew where he was, I'd get him off the street, but I think it's time that you, the Mayor, and everyone else be braced for the inevitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freeway is packed -- bumper to bumper.  Cars standing still in the hot sun. A hispanic man in his late forties, JUAN is seated in his Dodge Caravan when he sees someone in his rearview mirror man is using a stick as a cane.  The struggling man makes way along the shoulder very slowly. Juan reaches over to his passenger seat and turns over th L.A. Times.  Under the heading, "He's Back!" is Maurice's picture.  Juan quickly rolls down his window as Maurice passes by on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Hey, Maurice man -- keep going buddy! Maurice is startled at the man's yell, but then smiles wh the words register.  Maurice struggles forward. Juan keeps yelling encouragements... This grabs the atten of other drivers who realize who is walking past them.  O by one, car doors open and people call to Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop Maurice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go Mr. Parker! Cars start to HONK... More and more people turn to see th commotion... The YELLING AND HONKING IS JOINED BY WHISTLE

dialogues.speaker: AND CHEERS --
dialogues.text: Maurice can't believe it -- he tries to smile but can't h it.  His face tightens with every step.  His shirt is soi with blood.  He raises his hand and gives a weak wave to woman who holds up her little boy through the sunroof of car.

dialogues.speaker: A WCAU NEWS VAN
dialogues.text: parked in the traffic.  A NEWSREPORTER stares through binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you God! The crew quickly prepares their cameras and equipment.  T move like lightning.  In seconds they are shooting the cr and their hero. The air is CHARGED... THE NOISE GROWING, MORE AND MORE PE JOIN IN... LOUDER... People stand on top of their cars to a better view...

dialogues.speaker: A POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: stuck in traffic.  OFFICER DAWSON looks around as the PAR OF NOISE SURGES TOWARDS HIM.  He looks out his window and catches a GLIMPSE OF MAURICE LIMPING UP THE FREEWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Klein busts into Emory's office just as Adelle is about to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found him. Adelle is instantly charged with life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson's on the C.B. -- wants to talk with you Sarg.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ROOM
dialogues.text: Adelle and as many officers that will fit in the room are listening to the radio conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?  Where is he? Emory CLICKS TO LISTEN.  THE SPEAKERS EXPLODE WITH HONKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just getting off 280.  It's amazing Sarg... everybody's out of their cars and cheering him on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
